column1: We're fans of the GeoTrax series
column2: expecially the GeoMotion pieces.  However
column3: the Roundhouse was designed very poorly
column4: if at all.  There are several design flawas which cause major frustration to the kids
column5: I'll just explain the 2 main ones: 1) The roundhouse has 3 tracks leading up to it; two for it to pass straight through and one road which is perpendicular.  If the train exits through the perpendicular road
column6: since the roundhouse track is facing that direction
column7: it cannot came back around and enter through the straight road; the same is true if it exits via the straight side.  Furthering this problem is there is no manual crank to rotate the roundhouse track to the correct port
column8: so even if you wanted to manually turn the track to accept the train
column9: you can't.  The train gets jammed up and the kids get frustrated. 2) Many of the kits
column10: including the main set include additional cars aside from the lead engine.  They are to be attached behind the lead.  You cannot use a train with any length if you want it to fit in the roundhouse - all cars must be removed otherwise the track gets jammed up when the roundhouse tries to rotate and the other cars are attached from behind on non-rotating track.   The conecpt may have been good
column11: but the implementation was horrible and makes this the worst toy my kids got last year.  Furthering the problem
column12: is that I can't take it back since it doesn't dissasemble

column1: Disappointing self-help/literary guidebook that came utterly lavished with positive reviews; The New Yorker said of the book "Curious
column2: humorous
column3: didactic and dazzling...It contains more human interest and play of fancy than most fiction." Maybe I'm missing something or was just looking for something else
column4: but it seems to me that Alain de Botton's book is nothing more than a banal self-help book that is more eloquently written than the other works in this dubious genre. Botton doesn't offer the reader much in the way of literary analysis or explication
column5: rather
column6: he merely uses the life (and scatterings of the work) of Marcel Proust to launch into his mediocre prescriptions for living. Surprisingly
column7: little is actually said about In Search of Lost Time
column8: the author prefers to inundate the reader with scatterings of anecdotes about Proust's health problems and social life. There are a few sections which are worthwhile
column9: such as the great "what if it could have been another way?" conversation between Proust and James Joyce that reads like
column10: "PROUST [while taking furtive stabs at an homard a l'americaine
column11: huddled in his fur coat]: Monsieur Joyce
column12: do you know the Duc de Clermont-Tonnerre? JOYCE: Please
column13: appelez-moi James. Le Duc! What a close and excellent friend
column14: the kindest man I have met from here to Limerick. PROUST: Really? I am so glad we agree [beaming at the discovery of his common acquaintance]
column15: though I have not yet been to Limerick.  VIOLET SCHIFF [leaning across
column16: with a hostess's delicacy
column17: to Proust]: Marcel
column18: do you know Jame's big book?  PROUST: Ulysses? Naturellement. Who had not read the masterpiece of our new century? [Joyce blushes modestly
column19: but nothing can disguise his delight].  VIOLET SCHIFF: Do you remember any passages in it?  PROUST: Madame
column20: I remember the entire book. For instance
column21: when the hero goes to the library
column22: excuse my anglais
column23: but I cannot resist [starting to quote]: "Urbane
column24: to comfort them
column25: the quaker librarian purred..." (pg. 112).   There is also some interesting discouragement from Virginia Woolf upon reading Proust's great masterpiece
column26: "I detest my own vocabulary. Why be always spouting words? [...] Take up Proust after dinner and put him down. This is the worst time of all. It makes me suicidal. Nothing seems left to do. All seems insipid and worthless." (pg. 187).   Unfortunately however
column27: How Proust can Change Your Life is ultimately an overstated
column28: dressed up self-help book with many useless suggestions about how you should live. It is not substantive literary criticism. For the latter
column29: I suggest you seek out the work of Edmund Wilson.

column1: In the immortal words of Gene Autry: How can anyone be right
column2: when everybody's wrong?  Mr. Garea's (Amazon's Spotlight review) thoughtful
column3: well written critique on the Heisenberg portrayed in Mr. Rose's book is "compleat" (yuck yuck)
column4: and there is nothing I need to add.  Mr. Rose's slashing attack on Mr. Heisenberg is too simplistic
column5: fails to take into account the impact of the political
column6: economic and moral collapse of Weimar Germany on the German people
column7: and plays too heavily on what Mr. Rose sees as 400 unchanging years of Germanic totalitatian culture.  Heisenberg's harshest critics
column8: the Nobel Laureates Lenard and Stark with their Newtonian cause & effect "German Physics" (as opposed to "Jewish Physics" ie relativity & disputes about quantum mechanics a la Einstein and Niels Bohr)
column9: they were the ones falsely tied to a vision of Germanic Culture.  Not Heisenberg.  Where I part ways with Mr. Garea is in Mr. Garea's tounge in cheek portrayal of a Werner Heisenberg qua James Bond (maybe not Sean Connery or Roger Moore--more like a Timothy Dalton or George Lazenby) from Thomas Powers "Heisenberg's War: the Secret History of the German Bomb."  Whatever else he was
column10: Mr. Heisenberg was no smoothie--a common denominator for Bondness.  However
column11: I am convinced by Mr. Powers's thesis that Mr. Heisenberg did retard Germany's development of the atomic bomb.  No
column12: Heisenberg did not "fake" math calculations or create false evidence
column13: but as Mr. Powers carefully documents
column14: Heisenberg did work hard to create a false impression of the feasibility of creating an atom bomb.  Of the different opportunities that Heisenberg had for pushing development of a German A-bomb
column15: none could have been as fortuitous as the June 1942 meeting with Albert Speer.  Speer had just been appointed Hitler's honcho to get the economy on a war footing
column16: and develop some answer to the allies increasingly relentless and unanswerable bombing missions.  Additionally
column17: the Nazi regime needed to do something about the military reverses at Moscow.  If Heisenberg wanted to build an atom bomb
column18: Speer was ready to fund one.  Instead
column19: Heisenberg gave a deliberately obtuse presentation about the atom bomb.  Heisenberg was well aware that a reactor would create the fissonable element 94 (plutonium)
column20: but instead spoke generally of "transuranics."  This conscious fogging of the science intentionally left a false impression on Speer's science advisor
column21: a physical chemist named Lieb.  After the meeting
column22: Lieb (incorrectly) believed that only U-235 could be used for a bomb
column23: and that there was no viable way to separate U-235 from U-238.  Heisenberg knew better--plutonium could replace U-235--and how much fissonable material was needed for a critical mass: about the size of a pineapple.  Finally
column24: Heisenberg told Speer that perhaps a working reactor could be built in 1942
column25: but a bomb could not be built before 1945.  These dates are key for two reasons.  First
column26: the dates are outside the parameters that Speer needed
column27: and second: they were also damn good guesses.  Mr. Fermi created the world's first sustained chain reactor in Chicago in December
column28: 1942 and the US blew up the first bomb in July 1945.  Finally
column29: if Heisenberg really wanted to go all out on a German bomb
column30: there was Speer ready to write the big checks.  Instead
column31: Heisenberg & his people asked for piddling amounts of funding to continue basic research--so small that Speer promptly lost interest in atom bombs.  The importance of this June 1942 Meeting
column32: and the difference between what Heisenberg knew and what he told Speer is lost on Mr. Rose.  Heisenberg did consciously retard German developments of an A-bomb
column33: if only by deliberately creating several key false impressions--not exactly the stuff that wins hearts of Ursula Andress
column34: Jill St. John or even Sophie Marceau
column35: but it still counts.    Nevertheless
column36: how should we account for Heisenberg's inconsistent actions both during and especially after the war?  Mr. Powers suggests several reasons
column37: but I do not believe he gives enough creedence to Heisenberg's (and most Germans) fear & distrust of Soviet Russia.  Many individuals in the West initially excused Nazi excesses in the name of restoration of the economy (if only taming rampent inflation)
column38: and creating a bulwark against Stalinism.  One of Heisenberg's key co-workers was a (now former) communist sympathizer who returned to Nazi Germany after two & a half years in a Soviet prison
column39: with a forced bogus confession of being a Gestapo-Trotsky-Bukharin spy.  Something needed to be done about Stalin.  Moreover
column40: post WWI Germany featured seemingly endless rises and collapses of Governments.  At the time
column41: it was not unreasonable to believe that Hitler's thousand year reich would be replaced in next year's coup by the Christian Democrats
column42: or the Weirmarcht would throw out the Nazis
column43: and continue a secular (as opposed to Nazi racist paganism) military dictatorship.  The post WWII alibi of the "good germans" was not only that they "didn't know
column44: but that someone" needed to stop Stalin (not to mention the crap about building the autobahn
column45: but we digress).  Finally
column46: Heisenberg's seemingly inconsistent statements after the war are probably a combination of his foolish pride (OF COURSE he could have built a bomb--if he REALLY wanted to)
column47: and his awkward speaking style.  This last point is more of an impression--but Heisenberg was a physicist
column48: not a politician or a public speaker.  He could talk about science with exactness--but outside of that realm
column49: he left much to be desired.  In short
column50: I am convinced by Mr. Powers's arguments and the breath of his documentation.  Mr. Rose needed to pay closer attention to Powers's book
column51: and the documentation used by Powers.  As a final note on both this book and Mr. Powers's book--indeed
column52: since Heisenberg's death in 1976
column53: any book about Heisenberg--an important source as to Heisenberg's postwar views is the 1967 book "The German Atomic Bomb
column54: and a battery of extensive personal interviews, all by David Irving.  Mr. Powers merely cites this source--an undisputedly important source--without comment.  Still, as a historian, there is no question that Mr. Irving's reputation has taken a beating.  See, for example, Lying About Hitler: History
column55: Holocaust
column56: and the David Irving Trial" by Richard J. Evans.  Mr. Irving has recently been sentenced to three years imprisonment in Austria as a "holocaust denier."  What all Mr. Irving's personal beliefs
column58: and current legal woes add to the discussion of Heisenberg's activities from 1939 to 1945
column59: I do not know.  I have no idea what Mr. Irving's views were in 1965-1967
column60: when Mr. Irving extensively interviewed Heisenberg and wrote his book--and if Heisenberg was aware of those views in giving such time and access to Mr. Irving.  I only mention this as an additional piece of the Heisenberg puzzle that may (or may not) mean anything.  Be that as it may
column61: the bottom line is: Read Powers's book
column62: and not this one.  And Amazon is damn lucky to have thorough reviewers like Mr. Garea

column1: This novel was intriguing and fast. The plotline was engrossing

column8: and none are properly content. Most men are divorced (in Rusty's case

column12: then there is no hope for humanity. This major flaw

column14: was not sufficient to nullify the novel's advantages

column1: Caution
column2: Spoilers Ahead  This is a really awful book--one of the few truly laughable works of recent so-called "hard"science fiction.  While there are a lot of unrelated sub plots (with some admittedly interesting scientific "what if's
column3: ) the real plot line is simplistic, preposterous, muddle-headed and just downright offensive.  In Baxter's hypothetical near future, people of the future somehow reach back in time to create a bunch of super intelligent children whose mission (we find in the end, after countless red herrings) is...wait for it...to destroy the universe!  But, these kids are not the bad guys, because (in Baxter's view) the heat death" of the universe is somehow intolerable to the human spirit.  Thus
column4: by destroying the universe ("It's the wrong universe!" exclaims one of the children) a new one with different physical laws will be created in its place; and even though everybody in the old universe dies a terrible death
column5: it's ok because the new universe will somehow recreate the human mind and we will all live happily ever after in a universe that is eternal
column6: set free of the horrible laws of thermodynamics.  This is about the loopiest idea for a science fiction story I've ever heard.  It also puts Baxter squarely in the camp of the "we-are-the-only-intelligent-life-in-the-universe" crowd.  As you may know
column7: there are two lines of thought on extraterrestrial intelligence:  "we are alone" is one; and "we are not alone" is the other.  The math and statistics of each is camp points
column8: not to a right or wrong analysis of the data
column9: but rather insufficient data.  It's an argument tantamount to the existence of God
column10: with both sides stridently arguing their obvious correctness.    In any case
column11: this novel is pure drivel
column12: with an idiotic premise
column13: and an idiotic conclusion.

column1: Despite buying four copies of 'Call to Action' for my development team
column2: reading it through twice and making copious notes - I can't recommend that you read it.  It's not that it's bad - it's just not that good and I have to believe there are better books out there.  'Call to Action' describes itself as 'both a step-by-step
column3: how-to manual and a treatise on the true nature of conversion'.  In my opinion
column4: it fails to deliver on either count.  There's no doubt the authors know what they're talking about but
column5: ironically
column6: in a book dedicated to the process of communication
column7: they fail to communicate either a cohesive overview or a detailed 'how-to' of the subject.  There's a facade of structure and some whizzy acronyms like 'AIDAS' and 'MAP' but very little flesh is laid on those sketchy bones.  The introduction identifies the main cause of the problem - the book started life as a collection of disparate web articles interspersed by 'top-tips' from marketers 'in the trenches'.  The articles themselves give the sense of having been shoe-horned into a structure simply for the sake of it.  The 'top-tips'
column8: more often than not
column9: are completely irrelevant to the theme of the article they're paired with.  As a reader looking for greater understanding of the subject and some concrete next-steps
column10: this discordant content yields as much confusion as clarity.  On top of this
column11: the numerous typos
column12: misquotes
column13: repeated quotes and printing errors confirm that insufficient care has been taken in the preparation of this book.  It hasn't even been professionally proof-read
column14: let alone purposefully written.  So how come I purchased four copies?  The first half of the book does contain some exciting ideas such as developing content based on the persona of the visitor and planning precise conversion scenarios from the home page to the conversion point for each type of visitor.  The second half of the book is mostly padding and pointless repetition of the ideas in the first half.  I purchased the other copies of the book after reading the first half and expecting the second half to follow in a similar vein.  All things taken into consideration
column15: the book reads like a series of adverts for the authors' consulting services rather than as a 'how-to' or a treatise on the subject.  Other authors quoted in this book are:  Roy H. Williams
column16: Jared Spool
column17: Tamara Adlin and Jim Sterne
column18: and I'll be checking out their writings in my continued search for genuine 'how-to' content.  The Eisenbergs could have made this book more effective and much simpler.  They chose not to write for their audience and
column19: to my mind
column20: that makes them guilty of the same sin they condemn online marketers of - focusing on themselves instead of on their customers.  The Eisenbergs make the point that content created for offline advertising rarely translates directly to the web.  This book is proof that the reverse is also true

column1: Ted and Elinor have been married and experiencing fertility problems.  Like most couples that are trying to have a child of their own
column2: there are alot of emotions that both partners cannot understand.  Elinor is feeling completely useless and wonders why this is happening to her- and becomes ( understandably) wrapped up in her feelings
column3: and well as her disappointment with her body that she is unable to conceive a child with her husband.  After failed attempts for IVF and other complicated fertility tries- she becomes very emotional and sad.   Ted- just withdraws from his wife and meets a woman- Gina and starts an affair.  Gina has a son that "falls in love" with Ted and he mentors him. Elinor finds out about both Gina and her son and Ted's extreme interest and sort of "completely distances" herself from Ted and everyone.  Now my problem with this story is this- yes
column4: going thru something in a marriage such as infertility is terrible- The woman who goes thru 98% of all the tests
column5: drugs- hormones- feelings on an extended level needs to be comforted more than her husband.  We know he loves her- but................. to have the author then have Ted have and affair and she has a child- I thought just would "stab" Elinor in the heart- then to make matters sadder...........Elinor becomes pregnant and again looses the baby.......  Well at that point- I just lost all hope for a possible happy ending and I finished the book- but wow- I think I needed some chocolate to something that would brighten up my day and my mood.  Talk about SAD  :

The problem for me was the way the author conveyed her choice of subject material.  She soon began to sound quite self-indulgent and self-absorbed with this "pert orange rind"
column3: that "meandering back road"
column4: this "raised fork" and that "riotous bougainvillea".  It felt eventually like I was reading about someone  partaking of a huge buffet of the senses.  Interesting for a short time
column5: but for over 400 pages?  The book became numbing and repetetive.  Perhaps this is the result of patching together the various vacations she took over the 5-year period and using the same formula to convey the impressions of each one consecutively.  I would have enjoyed the book if it had been about 250 pages shorter and had concentrated on just one geographical location.  And if there had been more of the "location" described
column6: and less of Frances Mayes' perceptions of it.  It really seemed as if she was writing for an audience of one; herself.

 This book is crap. If you want to read 254 pages of contradicting theories backed up by little to no fact, this is the book for you. The one interesting and revelatory thing that I did pick up from this book is that the work produced by modern physicists is largely insubsantial and speculatory. The theories presented to explain space and time are no better than those created by those ancient Greek thinkers and philosophers who happened to have been proven wrong about things, or perhaps those of your average back-alley lunatic. These physicists, who should more likely be called sophists, simply pull from their anterior regions fantastic, thouroughly imaginitive structures to apply to the workings of the universe, simply because they truly have no legitimate answers.   Seriously, I'm an average guy, though fairly well educated, and I'm telling you, if you're the snooty, self-important type of intellectual who likes to make up smart sounding stuff (yeah, I said stuff") just for the sake of sounding intelligent

column1: As many of the other reviewers have said
column2: Michael Baigent seems determined to make the most of his current Da Vinci Code-related notoriety. That particularly shows through in this book
column3: which unfortunately is just a really lousy read. Baigent has showed previously (Holy Blood
column4: Holy Grail) that he is actually capable of writing in at least a relatively compelling style
column5: even if his contentions are fairly implausible. The Jesus Papers could definitely have done with some of this style - it gets so far off track in many places that its main contention (which is still basically the same as what he presented in Holy Blood
column6: Holy Grail) is almost entirely forgotten by the reader. This is a pity - even though I don't believe for an instant that Jesus somehow survived the crucifixion
column7: I was really interested to see how the story would be put together
column8: and I was sadly disappointed by this effort.  Much of The Jesus Papers retreads some of the same ground covered by Holy Blood
column9: Holy Grail
column10: but without nearly enough detail presented. It then gets severely sidetracked via a brief history of Judaism in Egypt and a discussion of theurgy (where Baigent appears to think he's invented the entire concept that ancient religions purported to involve direct communication with the gods)
column11: to end up with a story of Baigent's cave-crawling adventures in Italy. Some of this stuff might have been moderately interesting in its own right
column12: but a lot of it (particularly the bit in the caves) doesn't seem to connect to the main story in any logical manner. The other really frustrating thing is that every important document mentioned is either just tantalisingly out of reach
column13: the subject of a government and/or Vatican conspiracy to hide it from view
column14: in a language Baigent doesn't speak
column15: or a combination of one or more of the above. The "Jesus Papers" themselves are mentioned only briefly
column16: and of course the contents are untranslatable by the author
column17: so they don't actually prove anything at all.  The other complaint I have - and a couple of other reviewers have mentioned this as well - is Baigent's tendency to entirely dismiss the validity of anything written in the Bible
column18: unless it can be bent around to appear to support something he wants to say
column19: in which case it is clearly a reliable primary source. Sorry
column20: you can't have it both ways.  Either way
column21: The Jesus Papers really isn't worth the time. If you want the full theory
column22: read Holy Blood
column23: Holy Grail instead. If you want well-written Biblical scholarship
column24: pick a book at random and there's probably more in it for you than The Jesus Papers provides.

column1: I find the mostly 5 star reviews of Adam Bede rather puzzling. I am a great of lover nineteenth century English lit
column2: and have enjoyed the other three Eliot books I've read--Middlemarch
column3: Silas Marner
column4: and Mill on the floss
column5: the latter being far and away my favorite. However
column6: had I read Adam Bede first
column7: I may not have bothered to read other Eliot works.   Eliot's talent is indisputable. The other reviews do an excellent job of capturing what is great about her prose
column8: and many of those strengths are present in Adam Bede. What disappointed me most about this work were the characters. Each was far less complex than I have come to expect from Eliot
column9: and I found the saintliness of Seth
column10: Adam
column11: and Dinah boring
column12: almost irritating. It was hard to care about them. I also found
column13: despite the explanations Eliot provided
column14: that Adam's love for Hetty and Dinah's change of heart about marriage was implausible.  What sealed my opinion of this book was Adam's forgiveness of Arthur. After the devastation Arthur's actions caused
column15: it would have been superhuman to forgive him
column16: let alone regard him as a friend. When Arthur asserted that he suffered more than Adam
column17: I could hardly believe that Adam did not recognize yet another expression of Arthur's massive ego.  Despite the book's strengths
column18: this flaw
column19: together with one-dimensional personalities of the main characters
column20: relegates Adam Bede to an inferior status among Eliot's works.

column1: Attempting to fit a subject as enormous as World War II into one single volume of history is no mean feat. Whether Mr. Leckie's book is indeed the first such endeavour is open to debate - it may well be the first American one-volume history
column2: but by declaring his book a "first" without reservation
column3: Mr. Leckie rather sets the tone for the entire account: This is a short version of World War II seen from a purely (and chauvinist) American point of view. The account furthermore suffers from factual inaccuracies
column4: as the author makes every effort to belittle (or indeed ridicule) especially the British from Montgomery to Churchill
column5: demonize the Germans and generally overlook the decisive effort of the Soviets. But even if the reader accepts the book as a history of mainly the U.S. war effort
column6: the narrative is unbalanced by the excessive attention given to the island-hopping campaign in the Pacific. Mr. Leckie is
column7: I believe
column8: a former Marine himself
column9: and his loyalty to his old corps is touching - but damaging to his credibility as a writer of history. The number of individual marines portrayed
column10: the detailed decriptions of their weapons and equipment are completely out of proportion in a one-volume history of a conflict of this magnitude
column11: especially when taking into account that - in the larger scheme of things - the campaigns of MacArthur and Nimitz were little more than a side-show. The only decisive contribution to the outcome of the war provided by the island-hopping was the securing of forward air bases from which the air offensive against the Japanese mainland - culminating in the dropping of the nuclear bombs - could be staged. Such bases might just as well have been secured in China had the Americans used some of the ressources poured into the Pacific to support the Chinese war effort. Still Mr. Leckie allows the Pacific campaign to outshine even the monumental American effort in Europe. Only in his description of the Yalta conference does Mr. Leckie achieve an objective evaluation of the American contribution to the war - and its sad aftermath. The author deserves praise for his severe criticism of how President Roosevelt and his entourage allowed their biases and idiosyncracies to cloud their judgement at Yalta
column12: thus condemming half of Europe to communist tyrrany. Generally
column13: however
column14: the book seems in a sense oddly superflous: It is too subjective and selective as well as too factually flawed to be of use to readers who want to gain insight into the history of WW II by reading just one book
column15: while it falls far below the scholarly requirements of those who wish to study the conflict in detail

column1: I first read the Dance Hall of the Dead in high school.  Being a member of the Zuni Tribe
column2: and a resident of the town of Zuni
column3: it was quite interesting to see how much of the information concerning Zuni could be changed to fit the "theme" and plot of the book.  While these may seem like little details to most people
column4: it is quite disturbing to see how often Hillermans work is seen as accurate
column5: because of a reputation he has somehow gained as an "expert" on Native Cultures of the American Southwest.  Apparently
column6: he thought that all pueblo people are the same.  This is evident in the use of the last name of Cata
column7: which is not even seen in Zuni
column8: and is actually a last name seen only in the Rio Grande Pueblos.  In addition
column9: his interpretation or portrayal of the Sha'la'k'o ceremony as a "Dance Hall of the Dead" is simplistic at best.  While he may be an "expert" in Navajo culture
column10: it does not qualify him to comment on a COMPLETELY different society
column11: much less its sacred and complex kachina ceremonies.  Finally
column12: many native people
column13: such as the Navajo
column14: the Zuni and the Hopi (who have all been "featured" in Hillerman's books) feel that Hillerman's descriptions of ceremonies and rituals is just plain wrong.  As an outsider
column15: he has no business delving into or exposing the nature of such things as kachinas
column16: which we consider sacred yet dangerous.  Furthermore
column17: by exploiting our cultures for the sake of adding interest to a plot
column18: he seems to show a lack of respect for our cultures
column19: our religions
column20: and our tribes in general.   This in itself is bad enough
column21: but the worst thing is that people actually consider his novels definitive descriptions of Native culture.  There are many ethnological works out there that are available
column22: and they are NOT hard to find.  After all Zuni is one of
column23: if not THE most complex
column24: and most studied society on earth.  While I don't agree with people wanting to know "everything there is to know" about Zuni culture
column25: there are much better places to find out about "us" than a Tony Hillerman book

column1: What is this novel
column2: The Marble Faun
column3: that so many have said they "just simply must read" before travelling to the continent?  There seems to be some confusion about it
column4: not only in my mind
column5: but in the minds of others as well.  I know
column6: at least that the publishers have had their questions.  Why else would they be unable to agree on a title?  Even though they may have agreed to publish the book
column7: the British publishers spoke their mind at least and changed the author's title to Transformations.  After publication I'm sure they had wished that they had changed more than that.  It seems that the publishers also had to search for a selling point for the novel.  The prose alone could not carry sales
column8: so they have added photographs and made it "the great travel book of our age".  Of course
column9: I dare say people are buying the book more for the pictures than for the story itself.  The anticipation of seeing the piazza where Hilda's tower stands has intrigued the reader more than the murder
column10: and the characters' subsequent transformations and loss of innocence ever could.   The story itself
column11: centering around the actions of the four characters seems long and confused.  The characters float between scenes acting as they would anywhere else; the changing backdrops seem to act only as a way of keeping the travelling reader's attention.  Although Hawthorne makes sure you see that the four characters do in fact change (in such chapters as "The Faun's Transformation")
column12: the characters seem to be simply caricatures
column13: over-exaggerated looks at one type of person.  This is also accentuated by Hawthorne's use of epithets - such as "The Sculptor"
column14: "The Dove
column15: and The Faun".  Because of this the book has the air of being a presentation of four friends' romp through Italy
column16: rather than being the intricate tale of four characters' lives and relationships.  One may wonder why Hawthorne chose to publish the Marble Faun in one volume rather than serially
column17: as is common for his contemporaries.  The answer to me seems clear.  If a reader were to ever put this book down
column18: he would not have the heart to pick it up again

Albright has certainly accomplished a task few dance history scholars have: she gives us a comprehensive approach to dance from a variety of theoretical perspectives.  However
column2: I find her narrative style elliptical
column3: and I also find fault with her seemingly overzealous application of theory.  Albright applies many of the theorists currently en vogue in academia to dance study
column4: often with great results.  On the other hand
column5: the variety of rubrics she uses obscures the most important part of her study: her point of view. Her pairings are stimulating
column6: and certainly evocative.  Yet what results is a good amount of speculation
column7: not firmly grounded in rigorous historical/cultural research or in choreographic analysis.  I found each chapter glittered with fascinating ideas and concepts which could have been better fleshed out. Albright presents those interested in applying theory to dance with an interesting challenge: how can dance theory change its reputation from being a field of dilettantism to a field of scholarship?  I think the first step is to set out a cohesive analytic frame from the start of a study
column8: rather than throwing a hodge-podge of post-structural/post-colonial theory to bat against a corpus composed of two hundred+ years of history and thousands of works

column1: This is anything but an even-handed approach to the issue of trauma

column3: the arguments of which were equally biased yet well stated

column5: Lost and Found" along with Elizabeth Loftus' "The Myth of Repressed Memory." Neither are quite as unbalanced as this particular work but perhaps this may lend them more credibility

column1: I will not try to say that I asserted the painstaking
column2: analytic effort that some would argue is necessary for an appreciation of Heidegger. More than that
column3: I have no interest in doing so. It is largely agreed by the majority of his readers that this book deals with the question of being (existence)
column4: and my reading didn't lead me to any other conclusions. So as I said I have no interest in reading this a second time
column5: further
column6: deeper
column7: or slower.  Being and Time is chock full of invented terminology
column8: to the extent that Michael Inwood was able to profit from his publication of A Heidegger Dictionary. Whatever you might think the word "world" means
column9: for instance
column10: is not what Heidegger means
column11: and he will explain that to you throughout the duration of an agonizing 40 pages or so. This is the case with his entire vocabulary. If there was any need for all of the inventions and distinctions made by Heidegger
column12: I would not bring this up as a crticism.  Beyond the unventilated
column13: severely sober
column14: and utterly uninspiring character of Being in Time
column15: I also call attention to the futility of it's project. If Heidegger was right about the historical neglect toward the question of being
column16: perhaps more than 2000 years of historical peoples have been aware of something that eluded him: that there is no question of being.   Why is "the question of being" so problematic? Because it is unanswerable
column17: maybe. Or if it is answerable
column18: we're not in any position to answer it. "Being" implies some kind of unvarying stability that just doesn't make sense. And if you posit an idea that is so concrete
column19: so constant
column20: you can't just bend it to make it fit reality. You've already betrayed your questioning. Truth
column21: including the truth of being
column22: is a local phenomenon. Truth is not always and forever true - it's true when it's true. But Heidegger wanted an everlasting truth
column23: a dogmatic anthropology.  Worse than the general uselessness of his project
column24: and the toxic dregs left in his wake
column25: Heidegger is guilty of not even presenting his ideas in an intersting or thought-provoking way

column1: Luther Krank and his wife decide
column2: since their only daughter has joined the Peace Corps and will be away

column1: I have owned two books on "places to live" -- this one on retirement and another on general living areas
column2: thus I have a good basis for comparison. This book on retirement is mostly anecdotal and insufficient to make an adequate factual comparison among the various cities and towns. Why did the editor leave out the average cost of living for several of these cities
column3: for example? My other book had numerical ratings for all sorts of critically important categories like weather
column4: access to colleges and universities
column5: health care and hospitals (public and private)
column6: public transportation
column7: indoor and outdoor recreation
column8: the arts
column9: state sales taxes
column10: state income taxes
column11: property taxes
column12: housing costs
column13: general cost of living
column14: etc. The editor of this book includes some of this information but it is not consistent and not in any type of graphical or rating form so it is impossible to compare the various cities
column15: which is what we are inclined to do if we are choosing some place to retire. Another caveat: I think every book on retirement should have big bold letters printed on the cover
column16: in red: WARNING!! NEVER COMMIT TO A NEW CITY UNLESS YOU RENT THERE FOR AT LEAST SIX MONTHS!! Based on just a few vacation visits to our chosen retirement town
column17: plus information from this book
column18: we spent two months renting
column19: found and bought a house and have regretted it ever since. The glowing and gushing tales quoted about city and town life from every corner of the country in this book can be countered by equally dark tales of horror (we have more than a few about Whidbey Island
column20: WA). So do you see why I think those human interest stories that fill the book are truly useless in helping you choose your final destination? I also lived for five years in Ojai
column21: CA
column22: one of the editor's favored towns
column23: and I wouldn't want to be buried there
column24: much less step foot there ever again. What is one woman's hell is another's paradise. A book of dull yet solid statistics would have been much more useful
column25: in my humble opinion. Oh
column26: wait
column27: I have just the book you need
column28: easily ordered from Amazon! Try "Cities Ranked & Rated" by Bert Sperling and Peter Sander

 Of all the books written on the Reagan administration, this one may be one of the worst.  Poorly written with excessive attention to detail that makes the story plod, it makes one wonder if Frances Fitzgerald was a one hit wonder.   Fitzgerald's portrayal of Reagan as out of step with reality - starting with the book title and included throughout its content - is less of a description of reality and more, I suspect, the blowing off of ideological steam.  If you despise Reagan and think he was a dunderhead this book will do more than reinforce those beliefs.  If you want an intelligent and useful discussion of the Reagan Administration and its foreign policy walk right past this one

column4: the two-sided disc format with which all three DVD volumes have been released is a damage prone format.  Luckily I was able to get a full refund

column6: because Volume 3 contains some of the best episodes of the whole series.  If you are fortunate enough to get a DVD set free of defects
column7: then you are really in for a treat.  Bruce Timm and company bring the same high level of storytelling to Superman as they did on Batman: The Animated Series.  Of particular note is an ongoing subplot involving the villain Darkseid throughout the series.  It finally gets put front and center in several episodes of Volume 3
column8: and leads straight to the very powerful and dramatic series finale.  I felt that the finale could have been written out across three episodes instead of two due to the scale of the story
column9: but nevertheless it is a great ending for a great series

 Wright presents no new information about Al-Qaeda, leaves out plenty of information about Al-Qaeda and neglects the USA side of the road to 9/11."  Understanding Qutb's radicalization of Islam is important to understanding why Ayman al-Zawahiri and Usama exist and also why they failed at creating theocracies and were lame ducks until the USA found a use for them as an enemy.  What cannot be neglected is the myths spread about the United States by the Neoconservatives and followers of Leo Strauss.  The United States is not a unique and beautiful snowflake.  The liberal idea of individual freedom was decried by Strauss as destructive of the society of the USA and he told his followers to keep the public in line with grand myths about US exceptionalism.  After the the Soviet Union was kicked out of Afghanistan
column8: both Qutb and Strauss' followers believed they were the cause of it.  Since the Cold War the US has been working off of the "friend and enemy" model of policy formulated by Carl Schmitt and 9/11 presented the US with what Schmitt called a "state of exemption."  If you think jihad was the cause of 9/11
column9: ask yourself why Richard Clarke found Bush and his advisors saying find a way to tie this to Iraq hours after 9/11.  See the BBC documentary

After reading bits and pieces of this book from Borders
column2: I decided to order it online. Well
column3: all I can say is that this book was not worth my time and money.    I'll be very honest with you. He does have useful information such as manuscript formatting when submitting it to a publisher
column4: but that's as far as this book goes in terms of being informative.   The attitude of the writer was a definate turn off for me. At first I thought him amusing
column5: but as I kept reading this book I couldn't help feeling that he was being very arrogant and egotistic. In fact
column6: the whole book seems like an ego trip to me. Unlike a lot of writing guide books
column7: Monteleone actually tells us that all writers should aspire to be on the New York Times Best Seller List. Now
column8: throughout the years I have heard of lot of writers and novelists cautioning their creative writing classes   about the consequences of "writing for profit." If you make money on the way
column9: that's great. But making money shouldn't be your biggest reason in writing novels or short stories. You should write because you enjoy it. This
column10: I believe
column11: rings true. Of course
column12: everyone has different opinions about how and WHY he/she writes
column13: but Monteleone keeps shoving the Best Seller's List down the reader's throat. He even has a whole chapter dedicated on    promoting and marketing your novel (such as radio shows
column14: press release
column15: websites
column16: etc.)
column17: but barely touches on the subject of getting an agent. After devoting roughly 30 pages on how to sell your book
column18: he makes a few jokes and remarks about literary agents  and then moves on to other topics without telling us where and how we can go about obtaining one. His message is clear: "Making profit should be the writer's ONLY goal."     Also
column19: Monteleone is not shy about showing his disdain towards academics and people who dismiss the so-called "drugstore books" as low-end. He thinks they are cocky and therefore deserves no respect from him (who
column20: by the way
column21: wrote over 20 novels that are out of print). But as far as I am concerned
column22: he is the one who is the arrogant one that belittles the readers of this "How to" book. He has a very strong "it's either my way or no way because other people are all stupid and don't know what they are talking about" idea going throug his book. He lists a bunch of writers who were "the crassest commerical writers of their time" -- Twain
column23: Poe
column24: Dickens
column25: London
column26: Hemingway
column27: etc. But what about writers like Virginia Woolf
column28: D.H. Lawrence
column29: James Joyce and Kafka who were not commercial writers? Monteleone seems to be certain that people will still read Stephen King and Danielle Steel 100 years later.    He also states that he hates people who call themselves "authors" and not "writers" because he finds them (people who prefer to be called "authors") cocky and pretentious. This is one of many examples of Monteleone's arrogance. Again we see the "anyone who does not conform to my rules are stupid and ignorant buffoons" attitude.    One of the absurd rules he strongly suggest that we enforce while writing is "writing three pages a day." I have read other books on creative writing
column30: and although many professional novelists stress the importance of writing steadily everyday
column31: Monteleone is the first one to say that we HAVE TO write three pages a day. His reason for this ridiculous rule? Simple. The faster you write
column32: more books you can sell down the road. The issue of profit-driven writing surfaces again.     Overall
column33: I felt like taking a shower after I read this book. It's more about how to crank out a mediocre novel once a year and  doing everything you can to sell it. Although a good portion of  the book is about writing itself
column34: Monteleone's emphasis is on marketing rather than techniques or even writing a good
column35: solid novel. I felt more discouraged than anything because of his black/white attitude towards writing.     Monteleone ends his guide to writing with "if you want to tell him how much you enjoyed this book
column36: e-mail him at ~." Even that sounds cocky to me after reading this parade of "I'm so great" book. The whole books just sounds like a HUGE EGO TRIP
column37: nothing more.    I found books by Nancy Kress much more helpful than this one.  "The Complete Idiot's Guide to Writing a Novel" is one of the worst investments I ever made.

column1: Carlo Ginzburg
column2: author of CLUES
column3: MYTHS
column4: AND THE HISTORICAL METHOD (1989)
column5: THE ENIGMA OF PIERO: PIERODELLA FRANCESCA-THE BAPTISM
column6: THE AREZZO CYCLE
column7: THE FLAGELLATION (1988)
column8: and THE NIGHT BATTLES: WITCHCRAFT AND AGRARIAN  CULTS IN THE SIXTEENTH AND SEVENTEENTH CENTURIES (1983)
column9: is professor of  history at the University of Bologna and the University of California
column10: Los  Angeles.  In his work The Cheese and the Worms
column11: Ginzburg relates the story  of a medieval miller of Friuli
column12: Domenico Scandella
column13: called Menocchio
column14: who  is put on trial for heresy during the Italian Inquisition.  Ginzburg nicely  recreates the experience of a medieval trial-something monotonous
column15: seemingly endless
column16: and without apparent utility-at least to moderns who  generally suffer from a culture infused with impatient pragmatism.  This  relentless prodding of the inquisitors for answers to their hairsplitting  questions
column17: of Menocchio for meaning to his contemptible existence
column18: and of  Ginzburg for threads of connection between the trial proceedings and  possible sources is laborious.  Contemporary readers
column19: except for  specialists in cosmology
column20: derivative theology
column21: evolutionary anthropology
column22: and late medieval history
column23: likely will have little tolerance for such  esoteric musings. 	As stated
column24: Menocchio
column25: an obscure miller who is  nevertheless important to his local village
column26: is on trial by Inquisition  authorities for heresies which are numerous
column27: fluid
column28: and conflicting.   Ginzburg's main objective
column29: however
column30: is to get at the sources for  Menocchio's thinking
column31: especially his bizarre cosmological view involving  cheese and worms that are born in the cheese.  Like a relentless detective
column32: Ginzburg takes the reader into excursions
column33: asides
column34: and digressions.  He  explores written sources such as the Bible in the vernacular
column35: the Koran
column36: Sir John Mandeville's Travels
column37: Dominican Albert da Castello's Il Lucidario  della Madonna
column38: and many others.  He postulates an eclectic medieval oral  tradition from which Menocchio might have gleaned his ideas.  But all this  chasing of sources makes the reader feel like the proverbial rat trapped in  the maze.  There are many variations of possibilities for escape
column39: but there  is no resolve.  The discussion of  oral versus written sources goes on and  on.  Yet one thing is certain.  All oral tradition unless codified is  unpredictable and not easily discernable.  While a valid hypothesis  concerning source material for Menocchio's religious ideas
column40: oral tradition  remains unverifiable.  After all
column41: the written codification of the oral  tradition of Menocchio's trials is what Ginzburg found in the Archivio  della Curia Arcivescovile of Udine
column42: and this discovery sparked his writing  The Cheese and the Worms.  Furthermore
column43: Menocchio's suggestion that he is a  tabula rasa who simply creates these things in his own mind seems  incredulous.  That Ginzburg would take this seriously is all the more  unbelievable.  Menocchio is not unaffected by his environment which  includes written sources
column44: as Ginzburg so ably points out. 	With the  question of the origin of Menocchio's ideas about origins aside
column45: what is  left to discuss?  A Religionsgeschichtlich approach falls quick prey to  quaint anthropological inquiries.  This is what Ginzburg offers and little  more.  Perhaps more development of the Church hierarchy and the  consternation of the peasant against his elite accusers by way of a  sociological reading of religion in sixteenth century Italy would prove  useful.  But Ginzburg does little to develop this.  His real concern is  prodding the interaction of inquisitor
column46: miller
column47: and Menocchio's  acquaintances in order to find out about "Cheese."  When this is  attributed to an ancient Indian myth in the Vedas
column48: derived from residual  medieval oral tradition
column49: Ginzburg's work is done.   No more is left to  ascertain from Menocchio.  There is no complete characterization of  Menocchio-his family
column50: his work
column51: his accomplishments as mayor
column52: his business  dealings.  These things are not explored
column53: but these are what would make  Menocchio come alive and would give contextual meaning to his religious  ideas.  Why Ginzburg does not broaden his research is unclear
column54: but the  failure to do so leaves Menocchio as a religious oddity
column55: a heretic without  significance
column56: another faceless victim of an oppressive religious hierarchy.   Perhaps Ginzburg is unable to draw a more complete likeness of Menocchio  from the trial proceedings. 	Although the specialist might prefer to  study the complete text of these trials
column58: Ginzburg is superb.  As phenomenologist on this Friulian miller's  religious thought
column59: Ginzburg is without peer.  But THE CHEESE AND THE WORMS  can hardly be dubbed a serious Quellenforschung or traditionsgeschichte  except for a very narrow slice of sixteenth century Italian history.   Michael Hunter notes
column60: "Few will be able to accept Ginzburg's general  thesis
column61: his argument that Menocchio gives expression to a lively and  homogeneous peasant culture" (HISTORY 1981 66:296).  Further
column63: "The general reader will find the style opaque and the  results unexciting.  [The book is] for research libraries" (LIBRARY  JOURNAL 1980 105:1512).  At best
column64: Menocchio provides an illustration of  "the ingenuity and determination of the human spirit in face of  adverse circumstance" (see J. H. Elliott
column65: THE NEW YORK REVIEW OF BOOKS  1980 27:38).  At worst
column66: Menocchio is just another heretic that follows a  typical pattern with nothing exceptional
column67: so Ginzburg (p. 112).  To adapt  an old cliche

column1: When museum curator Bill Fanshawe vanishes just days before he is supposed to marry her best friend
column2: Dorothy Martin swings into action. It's too late for Bill
column3: and almost too late for his assistant--who is attacked in the museum. Dorothy decides the attack must relate to Bill's World War II service in the Royal Air Force. World War II veterans are a dying group
column4: but Dorothy and her friend Jane are able to track down a few survivors. Still
column5: what possible memories from a war more than sixty years in that past could justify assault--or even murder.   Dorothy discovers that sixty years matters relatively little to the English--who are still taking sides from the English Civil War of the 1600s. Those connected with Bill's air unit have strong memories--and continued anger over their losses and the way the war was fought.   Author Jeanne M. Dams's aging protagonist worries about her own health and future as she sees the decline in the WWII generation. Despite this
column6: Dorothy is hard to really like--or identify with. Her leaps to conclusion--that Bill's death must have something to do with the war (because he hadn't done anything in the sixty years since?)
column7: yet her failure to really get at the recently donated items is hard to understand. Because Dorothy had relatively few stakes in the outcome of the investigation
column8: reader interest is also reduced.   WINTER OF DISCONTENT is easy to read and engaging enough to be hard to put down. The 'American in England' approach lets American readers see England through American eyes--allowing the author to comment on aspects of society and history that an English protagonist would simply take for granted. I wish
column9: though
column10: that Dorothy could have been a bit more clever
column11: endangered
column12: or active--increasing my interest in the plot

column1: This book starts out with 120 pages of fluff C - mediocre at best and NOT why I bought the book.  Then it discusses briefly what microcontrollers are - seemed more like a bunch of scattered notes on the topic thrown together - again NOT why I bought the book.  Then it dives into Motorola chips and spends many pages talking about them - NOT why I bought this book.  Then the author uses really useless examples like sort routines (like that happens in microcontrollers a lot - better examples would have helped here) to illustrate whatever it was he was trying to illustrate.    Over all the book had the feel that the author tossed a bunch of lecture notes together
column2: some poor cut and paste C examples in the beginning and then just simply got lost in his mission to show us how to program microcontrollers in C. column1: This is the third in an expanding series set in a cod-Celtic world focussed on the "kingdom" of Deverry.  I was impressed enough by the first to buy the whole opening quartet
column2: and was sadly disappointed.  Books 1 and 2 are advertised as re-written
column3: and are reasonably polished.  The unrevised 3rd and 4th books have a first draft quality and increasing reliance on dialogue
column4: long stretches that read like film-script
column5: which isn't well-written and expose the poor quality of the character writing.  Book 1 dealt with some adult themes
column6: principally incest
column7: but in book 3 the heroine Jill is just gratuitously and tastelessly sexually abused.  The main gimmick of the series is that the main characters are linked by destiny through reincarnation
column8: and it records their "reunions" at different points in history.  In the first book the stories run parallel and reflect on each other.  As the series runs on the link between eras is weaker and the switch between stories is awkward and arbitrary.  In the later volumes
column9: in an attempt to open the story into an eternal battle between good and evil
column10: the author crow-bars in opposing schools of "Light" and "Dark" magic
column11: obviously "inspired" by The Force from Star Wars.  Her magicians also travel and fight on an "astral plane" extraordinarily similar to the world of Marvel comics hero Dr Strange.  In the final analysis these are teen romances
column12: with very few original ideas
column13: populated by lacklustre characters
column14: adequately written but operating on the law of diminishing returns.  I bought them so I had to read them.  Don't be sucked in

column3: this book will help know one except the author

column1: The title pretty much lets you know what you're getting. It's a grade-C howler but not as blatantly funny as I was hoping. Directed by exploitation film specialist Eddie Romero from a story that originally came from Jonathan Demme (long before directing "Silence of the Lambs" and "Philadelphia")
column2: this low-budget 1972 action movie was obviously filmed in the Philippines but set in some anonymous third world country. Playing hooker and small-time drug dealer Lee Daniels
column3: blaxploitation superstar Pam Grier plays the first half of the title role
column4: while long-forgotten Margaret Markov is the other half
column5: Karen Brent
column6: an unlikely Patty Hearst-like political revolutionary looking to partner with her comrades to overthrow the oppressive local government. Naturally antagonistic toward each other
column7: they are in a women's prison camp where they wear inexplicably bright yellow mini-skirts as uniforms. Run by a closeted warden and lecherous matron
column8: the prison is just an excuse for a lengthy shower scene and some half-hearted cat-fighting as Lee and Karen are pitted against each other. Of course
column9: they escape but shackled together a la "The Defiant Ones" and continue the cat-fighting until they attack a couple of nuns to steal their habits.  Meanwhile
column10: various groups of unsavory men are in pursuit - the loutish drug lord looking for Lee who stole $40K from him
column11: the rather passive revolutionaries looking for Karen
column12: and the incompetent police (who suffer the humiliation of exposing their privates to the drug lord). Needless to say
column13: everything eventually comes to a head but not before gratuitous nudity by a number of Filipino women
column14: a dog wears Karen's panties and some of the worst of 1970's men's fashion (one beer-bellied revolutionary wears a leather halter top with a straight face). There is a rather sad ending
column15: but what's truly sad is how much of the potential black comedy is missed entirely in this hilariously preposterous exercise. Sadly
column16: Grier is disappointing in this outing because her character is not allowed much to do beyond dealing with all the "jive"
column17: while Markov is an Amazonian blonde whom I am convinced is trying desperately to be credible. Since no one displays any talent for acting
column18: the rest of the cast is not worth noting
column19: except balding
column20: bug-eyed Sid Haig
column21: who uses his standard psycho persona as the drug lord. The 2003 DVD contains only the original trailer as an extra

column1: Electric Light Orchestra's third album
column2: the suitably titled 'On The Third Day'
column3: marked a significant step forward for the band. Following Roy Wood's departure
column4: co-frontman Jeff Lynne took the reigns and began to steer ELO's output towards the sort of material that would become staples of mid to late 70's FM radio. The results are mixed and there is more of a discrepancy between the high and low points on this record than elsewhere in their catalogue
column5: but it remains a decent effort from a band still very much finding its own musical identity.  The Beatles (or hypothetical post-Beatles Beatles...) comparisons are seemingly always levelled at Lynne
column6: a self-confessed fan of Britain's greatest musical export of the sixties. Here they are somewhat justified with Jeff's voice resembling John Lennon's at times and a handful of cuts resembling the sort of melodies crafted by Lennon and McCartney
column7: particularly on 'Bluebird Is Dead'. This was probably not a conscious effort on the part of Lynne
column8: although there is no doubt that with 'On The Third Day' he did consciously emphasise the rock elements of the band. As such this album is more accessible than its two predecessors and provides a couple of songs which
column9: '10538 Overture' aside
column10: have become the earliest canonised ELO tunes. 'Ma-Ma-Ma Belle' remains the band's greatest rocker thanks to Jeff's rough and ready vocal whilst the album's obvious highlight 'Showdown' pre-empts the more rhythmic hits the band would enjoy a few years later. The classical roots aren't disavowed completely (as evidenced by the delightfully overblown cover of 'In The Hall Of The Mountain King') but they have clearly taken a backseat to Lynne's broader vision. Even on the opening track the dramatic and heavily orchestrated instrumental 'Ocean Breakup' gives way to a reasonably pedestrian song entitled 'King Of The Universe'. 'Ocean Breakup' returns as a reprise a few tracks later but is cut short again
column11: so it's obvious to see where the band's priorities now lay.  As expected
column12: the new remastered edition is a beauty with bonus tracks for your dollar and the trademark of frustratingly short liner notes from Jeff Lynne. The man himself calls 'On The Third Day' an 'obscure' album; elsewhere
column13: an ELO historian claims it was a concept album of sorts. This seems to be stretching the truth a little - 'Eldorado' or 'Time' this is not - but for old fans seeking nostalgia or new converts wanting to explore the artistry of ELO further this is worth a look-in. The band doesn't hit their stride until its follow-up 'Eldorado' but 'On The Third Day' is a more satisfying listen than either of their first two albums

column1: The Crossing by Cormac McCarthy is an interesting but somewhat confusing look on the early west of America. The story begins with a father and two brothers trying to track and trap a wolf that had crossed over from Mexico. The Wolf is a mother and is supposedly carrying around pups with her. This part was particularly well written
column2: but became confusing when Spanish was being used heavily. In review of this part I believe that there was something deeper in the crossing of the wolf and thought of it as a metaphor to immigration issues. The short-lived story of the capture of the wolf was ended by a cleverly placed trap by one of the sons. 	Instead of killing the wolf as some would have expected (though that would have ended the book rather abruptly) the two sons decided to return the wolf to Mexico. After this happening the brothers go on various adventures including running away with a heartthrob
column3: attempting but failing to join the U.S. army and crossing in and out of Mexico a total of 3 times.  	This was a well written book but there were many useless characters in it that just seemed to distract you from the actual point. The over use of the Spanish language confused me and would confuse anyone who doesn't speak it. I thought this book lacked motivation and suspense
column4: but because of the author's brilliant mastery of the English language he was able to entangle me enough to finish it all the way through

column1: This book was assigned to me for summer reading for Advance Placement Government class.  I got it through borders and paid high price for it
column2: I highly suggest buying it used through amazon.com.  In the beginning this novel seemed very interesting with its unique insider perspective however this insider perspective drowned the novel with annoying anecdotes.  The perspective was lost with countless examples that were perfect cure for when I was in desperate need of sleep. The author states his views and makes his points in the first page of two of every chapter and for the next 10-20 pages it just filled with every moment of his 30+ year experience at D.C.  This novel is 700+ pages long and could very easily be trimmed down to under a 100 and still have a greater impact.  So I would advise to buy it used then just read the first page of every section

column1: This book
column2: is not for newcomers to statistics. It often assumes a well versed backround in probability and statistics (and I suppose a decent background in calculus). There is often little explanation for examples and theorems. Often the exercises and examples require the solution to previous exercises. This is extremely frustrating and often discouraging. Many times I would find myself being refered to an example in a previous or future chapter whose solution refers to a problem that needs to worked out. I have an undergraduate degree in math and am by no means a genius
column3: but compared to many well written math texts
column4: the clarity and conciseness leaves much to be desired. The exercises do not go from easier to more difficult but from difficult to difficult. Often the concept that is trying to be illustrated could be done in a much simpler problem.  That all said
column5: the book is fairly well written given the aforementioned weaknesses. My professors seem to like it as do a couple of PhD students

column1: Although Widdowson is the editor of the Oxford Introductions to Language Studies series this book does not have the same feel as others in the series. The format is the same with a selection of readings following the author's introduction. However
column2: this book seems to have been written as an introduction for experienced linguists. It contains all of the information but with none of the details that would make it a pleasant read for novices. Ultimately
column3: trying to squeeze everything there is to be said about linguistics into 77 pages is an impossible task and makes for an unprofitable read.  That said
column4: the selection of readings is particularly strong and Widdowson asks some pointed questions of each author. It is at times very apparent what answer he expects because he goes on to ask questions based on what his answer would be. This would annoy those who disagree with him.  This book only rated two stars because I expected more from the series editor. Widdowson seems to have missed the second word of the series title: introductions. Only those with a graduate level reading ability in the field of linguistics would find this book enjoyable. I would recommend Jean Aitchison's book instead (0340870834). It is highly readable and geared more for the novice

column1: I'm a student taking a color class at my local junior college and this is the required text. This book is the most awkward book I've ever read. The authors continually repeat themselves and ramble on about nonsense. The authors actually have the exact same sentences repeated within a chapter. This book is poorly written and poorly edited; there are misspellings
column2: and incorrect information! While discussing complementary color schemes
column3: the authors explain that complementary schemes involve colors directly opposite on the color wheel. Then they list the following examples "red-green"
column4: "blue-yellow"
column5: and "orange-violet". These exampes are INCORRECT. Blue and orange are complements
column6: as are yellow and violet. If the author can't get such a simple statement correct
column7: it seriously comprimises the rest of the text. In short
column8: this book is simply the most awkward
column9: frustrating book I've ever read. Please please please
column10: spare your sanity and buy another book on color.

After reading so many positive reviews
column2: I decided to try Skeleton Man as my first Hillerman novel.  Unfortunately
column3: I'm about 100 pages into it and have decided to give up on it.    I read a lot of novels and have never really had a problem with this before
column4: but I find Hillerman's writing style to be very choppy and awkward.  I find I have to re-read sentences to catch the meaning because it just doesn't flow smoothly.     Here's an example of one paragraph that I opened to randomly:  "Getting this ceremonial procession from Tuve's village on Second Mesa to the canyon rim and them to the riverbank involved describing several more stops for prayers and offerings
column5: the placing of painted feathers in the proper places with the proper songs
column6: and putting prayer sticks where the proper spirits traditionally visited.  By the time Tuve had brought them to the Hopi shrine at the tribe's cliff-bottom salt deposits
column7: Joanna Craig had looked at her watch three times that Chee had noticed.  Navajo fashion
column8: he hadn't glanced at his own.  Tuve would finish when he finished."  It's like he talks in short cuts that you're expected to follow. When I'm reading this book
column9: my mind is wandering all over the place because the text doesn't draw me in.  I'm glad he has a lot of fans out there
column10: but I'm not one of them

column1: I bought a GustBuster umbrella several months ago
column2: expecting that it'd be the last umbrella I ever needed. Wow
column3: was that a bad decision. This "windproof" umbrella had two of the spokes break in a light wind (the weather report said the winds that day were only about 15 miles per hour). So I e-mailed the company because I remembered that it had a "lifetime guarantee." They told me that I'd have to ship it back to them (which is perfectly fine)
column4: but I'd also have to pay them $10 for their trouble. What kind of lifetime guarantee is that? For $10 or less I could buy another umbrella locally. Their product has proven that it's NOT superior and it DOESN'T live up to the claims they make for it.  Don't spend all this extra money on a GustBuster because you think it'll work better. It won't. Go out and buy a normal umbrella for 1/3 or 1/4 the price of a GustBuster -- you'll probably get the same amount of use out of the normal umbrella
column5: and you won't be paying an outrageous price for something that doesn't work the way their marketing claims

column1: Don't believe the hype.  This book is not a masterpiece
column2: but if you are able to stick through the piles of metaphorical images that are at moments beautiful but most often don't quite make sense together and make it to the end of this novel you'll be pleased to find some actual action and true emotion in Justine.  It took me a very long time to read through the first half of this book.  The narrator is irritatingly affected and the writing drags with a myriad of descriptions that are uneffective at creating a cohesive picture.  But what kept me going were Durrell's secondary characters.  He has a nack for capturing and creating quirkiness that borders on bizarre and his stories of the more minor men and women in Justine are striking
column3: emotional
column4: and entertaining.  I am glad that I was able to make it to the end of the novel (there is a hospital scene that made it all worth while)
column5: but I do regret that I recommended this novel to my bookgroup and I do not plan to complete the quartet

column1: Let me start by saying that I've got a high tolerance for boring. But this book is worse than boring. This book's been written by a woman who apparently lacks a basic understanding of the grammatical rules of the English language (let's not even get into the numerous spelling mistakes making appearances throughout the text). And it's been edited by a person who apparently has no qualms with allowing said poor grammar and spelling to see the light of day. On at least every page I've read so far there's been at least one glaring error. I have read over 100 pages of this atrocity (lucky me). These people need a good copyeditor.  In addition
column2: they really need to work on sentence flow
column3: because the text is full of sentences that appear to have no logical relationship to one another - and have been plopped down next to each other anyway.  I'm not going to claim I'm a genius at this stuff
column4: but I'm not trying to write a $50 book. There may well be some good ideas here
column5: but even a well-educated adult (maybe even ESPECIALLY a well-educated adult) is going to be able to get through this without being tremendously distracted by the poor quality of the writing. It makes me want to hurl that I spent money on this thing. I can't wait to be done using it so that I can sell it to some other poor unsuspecting soul - or some other poor grad student like me who won't have a choice about reading it.   If you're a professor
column6: please show mercy on us all and leave this out of your syllabus. It's AWFUL

column1: Keynes was no doubt an influential economist.  His theories and 'expertise' on economics influenced the post-New Deal economic policies of the United States and the internationalist wealth redistribution schemes like IMF.  However
column2: his ideas on economics failed miserably and it was application of Keynesian ideas that wrecked so much havoc on the U.S. particularly in the 1970s with the stagflation (an inflationary recession with unemployment which was theoretically impossible accordingly to Keynesism.)  We have Keynes to thank for budget deficits and the nebulous idea that we can spend ourselves into prosperity through the largesse of the federal government.  Read Planning for Freedom or Socialism by Ludwig von Mises instead

column1: This is the first Elliott Kalb book I've read and I'm extremely disappointed with the numerous errors that pepper this book throughout.  Younger readers who are trying to learn something about the greats of the game will be inundated with incorrect or contradicting information and readers who consider themselves somewhat educated about baseball history will soon become annoyed at the mistakes
column2: which seem to adorn every single page.  Kalb states in one player's comments that the first All-Star game took place in 1934 (incorrect)
column3: then in another player's comments writes that the first All-Star game was played in 1933 (correct).  Confusing
column4: no?  This is one of many examples that I found.    It appeared that some errors were the result of just plain laziness
column5: while others came from poor research.  In the Mike Schmidt chapter
column6: Kalb writes: "In 1977
column7: he (Schmidt) scored 114 runs on his .274 batting average.  That's the record for most runs scored on a sub-.280 average in baseball history."  Not only is that NOT the record
column8: it's not even close.  The record is held by Hub Collins
column9: who scored 148 runs while hitting .278 in 1890.  In fact
column10: there have been 73 times in baseball history that a batter scored at least 114 runs while hitting below .280.  And if you ignore the 19th century and only consider modern-day (1900-present) players
column11: Red Rolfe holds the record with 143 runs scored on a .276 average in 1937.  The feat has been accomplished 36 times since 1900 and Schmidt is tied for 32nd (and last) place.  This may be nitpicking
column12: but it's errors like this that make me not take this book seriously.  My second point of contention is that Kalb rarely "sells" his opinions why he thinks one player is better than another.  He states facts (sometimes even correctly)
column13: and compares the numbers and contributions of each man
column14: then leaves most of the job to the reader to decide who was better.  But I bought the book hoping that "Mr. Stats" could convince me why one player should be considered better than another or perhaps change my mind about some of my own opinions.  Instead he came on with all the  conviction of a wet noodle.  I'm not going to bash Kalb for his rankings because
column15: frankly
column16: they're based on his opinions and he's entitled to them.  Just because I may disagree doesn't make him wrong and me right.  But his infatuation with Barry Bonds and insistance on bringing up his name every chance he could
column17: became overbearing at times.  We get it
column18: Mr. Kalb.  You think Barry Bonds is the greatest player of all time.  It's bad enough that I had to read about it  on the first page
column19: let alone be constantly reminded of it on every other page.    As you can tell by now
column20: I wasn't impressed with the book at all and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.  It wasn't particularly well written and there are too many errors and inaccuracies to receive my endorsement.

column1: I am almost done with this book....but reading it has not been the experience I had thought it would be.  I realize that this book is about her travels towards faith and that is a uniquely individual thing
column2: but I am really struck by how self-involved the author is...her brand of Christianity seems solely to be how can God enhance her life and the life of those she loves.  It all revolves around how finding God has improved her life...with nothing about what God requires of her.  I don't consider myself Christian in the born again sense but I was certainly raised in a Christian manner...by parents who volunteered in a million different ways in order to serve God and those less fortunate.  Why doesn't Anne Lamott put down the pen and go work in a soup kitchen?  She definitely writes well and I enjoy her style
column3: but she needs to get outside her head

column1: I came across McCarry after reading Mark Steyn's claim that he was another real ex-spook novelist and better than LeCarre.  Well
column2: lots of things are better than recent LeCarre
column3: but at least to judge by this book McCarry is a journeyman writer who doesn't come close to comparing to LeCarre in his prime.    Yes
column4: his intelligence background lends surface realism to his descriptions of a hunt from one end of the world to the other-- the part set in a remote corner of China where Kafka meets Genghis Khan is especially convincing and amusing.  But too much of this covers standard airport novel stuff-- the old (by now very old) Nazi in South America
column5: the way-too-much-to-swallow-mystery (which covers all the ground from ancient Judea to Osama bin Laden-- by way of Heydrich's Czechoslovakia!)
column6: the band of retirees assembled to solve it all who fall somewhere between Doc Savage's Fantastic Five and one of those aging-actor-work-program movies like The Wild Geese.  The real point is that McCarry is telling a plot-- a whopper of one-- and can only tell it by sending his main character from one part of the world to the next where
column7: conveniently
column8: someone who we are told will tell him nothing promptly tells him everything.  LeCarre
column9: on the other hand
column10: uses the dilemmas of spying to explore character.  The mystery in Tinker
column11: Tailor could hardly be smaller (one's a mole
