column1: On one hand
column2: this book makes useful points and divorce and its impact on children and offers better alternatives. The problem with it is that most of the evidence is anecdotal. I don't think a lot of the problems the people in the book had were due to divorce
column3: but to the way their parents handled the divorce. Many of them either leaned on their children too much for support or they went from giving their children attention and affection to ignoring them in favour of work and other mates. A lot of the problems could have been lessened with more care. Especially in the case of the fellow who had a congenital heart defect. He needed attention and help
column4: he didn't need to be shunted off to the side. I'm also reading about attachment issues and how they can impact a person from the time they are a baby to an adult. If a person has to divorce
column5: they should ask themselves if it is the right thing to do and if all other options have been exausted. Forcing people to stay together in a stagnating marriage seems a bit cruel to me
column6: like in the case of the intact family she used as an example.  Also
column7: I do not agree with her stating that children don't notice the tention and fighting in their family. They do. Children notice more than people give them credit for. Like so many experts she paints with too broad a brush. She uses too many generalizations. It lessens the impact of her argument. But
column8: a lot of the advice she gives to the system could be used to make divorce easier on parents and children. Divorce isn't going away anytime soon
column9: but
column10: with responsibility and care perhaps it can be easier on children. It is hard for children to adapt to changes. I suggest looking at the advice she offers
column11: but question her methods and conclusions

column1: I started writing code for the web back when you could still order it as a text only service.  DOS ruled the day
column2: and there were no ads plastered on every site.  This is the first product that takes HUGE STEPS BACKWARD in useability
column3: functionality
column4: and performance since the public birth of the web.  Unlike the previous reviewers glowing account of AS 4000 I am looking at new software because the service that this company provides and their complete lack of a proactive nature with regard to its useability have rankled me one too many times.  To wit:  1.  I am running a dual core 3.0 with 1 gb of memory and the 3d draw is slower that previous versions. 2.  Tech support had the audacity to tell me that going to a drop down menu to rotate an item selected is faster than a right click of the mouse and a context menu that would allow me to do the same from that menu.  This is a step backward of at least 10 years.  Previous versions had the right click menu which also had delete and other frequently used commands available.  Really piss poor on their part to eliminate this feature alone. 3.  Despite a fast newer machine
column5: once you select an item you have to wait before you can move it by selecting it a second time.  Pitiful. 4.  Won't import standard dxf files without saving them as one layer.  Making a product that won't play nice with others is a bad thing.  I have other issues
column6: but just don't want to spend any more time on this company or their products.  If I ran my business and failed to listen to my customers like punch
column7: I would be out of business.  Bottom line:  NO LONGER RECOMMENDE

column1: First of all
column2: I can't believe Trace got better reviews than Predator.  Predator was 1000 times better
column3: but that's still not saying much.  Trace was just awful.  The worst in the series.  I can say with the certainty of the Great Scarpetta
column4: that Patricia Cornwell did not write this book. One of her ghostwriters
column5: who probably hates Scarpetta
column6: wrote it.    This book is incomprehensible.  The story lines are disjointed
column7: disconnected--just plain bad.  There is no follow through; the reader doesn't get the satisfaction of having everything tied together at the end.  What happened to Pogue?  Dr. Paulsson?  Mrs. Paulsson?  Dr. Marcus?  And what about Fielding? All of a sudden Fielding has a horrible skin condition and he's no longer in great shape and good looking.  Is this all because the Great Scarpetta was fired and moved away and the stress of life without her has ruined his physical appearance?  That's pretty riduculous. And the motivation of the killer is so weak and SOOOOO absurdly stupid
column8: that I can't believe that Patricia Cornwell approved this awful imitation.   I'm so SICK to death of Lucy and her bad relationships
column9: and I just can't stand Rudy. Also
column10: in this book Lucy's father is now Cuban
column11: instead of Brazilian
column12: like he has been in the 12 previous books.  This ghostwriter has obviously never read any of Cornwell's Scarpetta novels.  Cuba and Brazil are two totally different countries and cultures!  To me
column13: this is a huge oversight.  A good author takes note of every detail of the characters s/he creates
column14: and I'm pretty sure that Cornwell isn't careless.  I digress...And then there's Benton and Kay
column15: back together and back into the swing of their passionless
column16: unfulfilling relationship.  Do they even like each other?  There's such tension and animosity between them.  Especially since Benton was never really dead; he was just undercover.  That whole story line was never explored in this horrible book. Even more evidence of poor ghostwriting--that was the greatest oversight. There's no hashing out of feelings and talking things through. All we're left with is Benton's five sentence explanation in Blow Fly. And Marino...I was horrified and acutally felt embarrassed when I read the part of Scarpetta taking pictures of Marino's injuries.  I don't want to give it away
column17: if you haven't read the book.  That part is humiliating.  If you are a Scarpetta fan
column18: you'll read this book despite the bad reviews.  In fact
column19: you have to read it because you have see for yourself how truly terrible it is.  Just don't buy it.  Borrow it from the library

column1: C. S. Lewis exposed the circular reasoning in Hume in the book "Miracles."  David Hume was not a skeptic.  He was a freemason and therefore a gnostic.  He was only skeptical of nongnostic positions
column2: such as Christianity.  He was an apologist for gnosticism.  He had blind faith allegiance to the masonic lodge and its creed.  His argument against miracles is his chief argument against Christianity
column3: and it suffers from circular reasoning.  Circular reasoning you exclaim?  Yes.  Hume argued that miracles violate uniform experience.  However
column4: if uniform experience is against mircales
column5: then they cannot happen.  Uniform experience is his presupposition.  But
column6: uniform experience is defined to exclude miracles.  If they didn't happen
column7: well
column8: they didn't happen.  This begs the question.  I have a better argument than Lewis's.  I would simply point out that pure logic cannot dispense with the empirical question of whether miracles happen.  Afterall
column9: mathematics is made up of tautologies.  As such
column10: mathematics or logic or any formal reasoning cannot have physical meaning.  Pure logic
column11: as Hume employs
column12: cannot tell us anything about the world.  Therein lies the sophistry.  It boils down to the distinction between analytic statements and synthetic statements.  Whether or not miracles happen depends not on logic
column13: but on the existence of God who intervenes in human affairs.  As the former atheist Antony Flew said
column14: it is impossible to argue against the existence of God in light of the evidence of intelligent design of the universe.  If anyone went to the moon and found a house there that supplied oxygen
column15: food and other human necessities
column16: they wouldn't hesitate to posit a creator of that house.  So why would anyone question the existence of God in light of this wonderful planet that supports our lives?  What is remarkable about him is how irrational he is.  He possesses a flair for writing and shows great promise in reasoning.  Yet
column17: he sacrifices good reasoning for pushing his gnostic agenda.  It's like a person who graduates from medical school who decides to murder patients
column18: or a graduate from law school who chooses to rob banks.  He tries to use reasoning to support irrational thought.  Hume was a strange man.  The engine is running
column19: but there's no one behind the wheel.

column1: John Horgan is one of those intellectually challenged journalists who only want to write about big things because they are too proud to be interested in any particular "small" question that science tries to solve. So many of these journalists choose a truly big theory - namely that there is something seriously wrong with the scientific method and with science and that science may be ending.  Of course
column2: the scientists consider all such journalists and "thinkers" to be cranks
column3: for a very good reason. The very existence of our civilization - something that distinguishes most of us from the monkeys - is based on certain general principles that also underlie science and these principles will never be given up unless the whole humankind is really doomed.  Careful thinking that is as quantitative as possible and the elimination of ideas that have turned out not to be viable are two examples of such principles.  John Horgan
column4: is his attempt to earn his 15 minutes of fame - plus some bucks - has written this nasty book that not only offered a whole sequence of possible theories how science can finally be killed and how horrible science is. This book was also full of personal attacks against the scientists
column5: their appearance
column6: their voice
column7: and all of their other superficial and unimportant characteristics.   John Horgan was - and still is - just far too dumb to be able to look into the scientists' thoughts
column8: the entities that make the scientists important. At least
column9: he could analyze their "quirkiness" and write confusing stories about the scientists and aliens that have nothing to do with the essence of the research done by the actual scientists.  Such crappy books have always found a lot of readers who eagerly buy them. However
column10: the books have no lasting value. It's been almost 10 years since the book was released
column11: and all of its predictions look even more absurd now than they looked 10 years ago. The science hasn't ended
column12: Edward Witten is still the most respected physicist
column13: and John Horgan is still just a despicable nobody.  Also
column14: this book is the 360
column15: 000th most successful book at amazon.com; compare with The Elegant Universe that has been among the top 1
column16: 000 books more or less for the whole time. Nevertheless
column17: the big doomsayers and science-haters will never close their mouth. So they still flood the book market with many new crappy books that are very similar to Horgan's book - Troubles with Physics
column18: Not Even Wrong
column19: and various feminist diatribes against the male science - books that will surely share the fate of this nonsense written by Horgan. But before the time will speak
column20: thousands of new stupid consumers will buy these books and they will say how terribly inspiring the content is

column1: After reading this book
column2: I would have to say Michael Apple did a wonderful job using examples to describe how modern public schools in the United States are flawed. He also did a good job introducing ideas
column3: which might have been alien to many people
column4: regarding elements of public education in America. However
column5: it seems he spends too much time on the tautology of blaming Republicans for the misfortunes and pratfalls of present pedagogy. One must remember that Democrats and Republicans are both cut from the same cloth. In addition
column6: if Apple wants to scream bloody murder about how many blemishes that Republicans have caused public education
column7: he needs to remember that Democrats really have not made it any better. The "No Child Left Behind" act is something that both the left and the right support
column8: and after working in public education for over a year
column9: I can tell you this act really does not work.  Apple does explain notions of Channel One and product placement in public schools
column10: which then dictates curriculum. He also goes into detail about how the media influences education and contemporary society. Nevertheless
column11: he spends more time pointing fingers and telling you what is wrong. However
column12: he never expresses any lucid or tangible means to ameliorate this quagmire facing our youth and public education.   There is a fine line between making a wonderful argument and whining like a baby. Apple does a great job performing the latter. Mind you
column13: Republicans are not perfect politicians by any stretch of the imagination. Just look at some of the things that have happened over the past few years. Yet
column14: Apple's diatribe seems more like whimpering
column15: instead of fighting back
column16: or addressing a solution to all the things
column17: he is complaining about. Overall
column18: this is an interesting read
column19: but Apple is nowhere near the philosophical icon of John Dewey.

column9: or have to copy all the DVDs that I need to use on multiple machines.  If you are not sure whether to get this
column10: I'd consider buying your movies from iTunes and using an AppleTV
column11: or some other similar model.  You might also consider any fair use provisions that let you keep a copy of the DVDs you rightfully own for permanent insertion into this device (although the interface is still absolutely horrible).    If the remote and user interface were actually functional and elegant
column12: I'd probably feel differently about this product

column1: I don't know what I was expecting from Hubert Sumlin. Unfortunatley Muddy had a better voice and so does Willie Dixon for that matter. All the session men sound like add-ons to the old band

column1: I wanted to give this book a good review
column2: but I cannot recommend it for a beginner. Like many readers
column3: I came to it because I wanted to learn about philosophy and it was the only book on subject that I had heard of. The good news is that after 800 pages
column4: I still wanted to learn more. The bad news is that I still knew very little.   The first problem is that the book has way too much breadth for a beginner. You do not need to spend 100 pages on Greek philosophy before even coming to Plato. For those that are interested in purchasing the book
column5: I would suggest trimming the list to: Plato
column6: Aristotle
column7: Aquinas
column8: Descartes
column9: Berkeley
column10: Hume
column11: Kant
column12: Locke
column13: Leibniz
column14: Hegel
column15: and then everything from Schopenhauer onwards.  The second problem is that the book is dated. Russell wrote it during World War II and there have been huge developments in philosophy since then. Some examples include the decline of the logicst program and logical positivism
column16: the development of ordinary language philosophy
column17: the later Wittgenstein
column18: and a lot more on pragmatism beyond William James (such as Quine)
column19: and a rebirth of Christian philosophy from within the analytic and empirical traditions that Russell advanced (such as the works of Alvin Plantinga and William Lane Craig). It is standard for contemporary introductions to philosophy to cover most of these later developments.  A third problem has been well commented on by many other reviewers
column20: which is Russell's bias and his dismissive treatment of philosophers that he does not agree with.   Finally
column21: although histories have their place
column22: they are not a good way to actually learn philosophy. Instead they are best used for becoming familiar with the major names and what they did. To actually learn philosophy you need an introductory book that directly focuses on the ideas.   My advice to someone new to philosophy is to buy 'An Introduction to Philosophical Analysis' by John Hospers. It is a gentle but rigorous textbook that is ideal for the first timer. It has a bias towards atheism
column23: but theists should not pass up such a well-written book. Then follow it up with the even more rigorous and thorough 'Philosophical Foundations for a Christian Worldview' by JP Moreland
column24: even if you aren't a Christian. It has the best explanations of epistemology and metaphysics that I've seen. At that point you may want to get some logic under your belt
column25: so if you are still ambitious
column26: buy 'An Introduction to Logic' by Harry Gensler. The logicola software that accompanies the book is ideal for learning philosophical logic through self-study.

column1: Mr. Dennett's book demonstrates the ignorance
column2: irrationality
column3: and dishonesty  of humanists. Discussing the meaning of word materialsim
column4: Professor Dennett says:  "In its scientific or philosophical sense
column5: it refers to a theory that aspires to explain all the phenomena without recourse to anything immaterial--like a Cartesian soul
column6: or "ectoplasm"--or God. The standard negation of materialistic in the scientific sense is dualistic
column7: which maintains that there are two entirely different kinds of substance
column8: matter and ...whatever minds are supposedly made of." (p. 302)  Philosophers stopped believing in dualism a thousand years ago with the development of metaphysics. A modern view is that man is an indefinability that becomes conscious of its own existence.   The philosophy that God does not exist is not materialism
column9: it is naturalism. Materialism is the view that all that exists is matter. Materialists frequently say that free will is an illusion and that the experience of the existence of oneself is some kind of epiphenomena. (In a quote below
column10: you will see that Dennett puts free will in a list of things people belief in.)  It is not clear from the book whether Dennett is a materialist
column11: but he is certainly a naturalist. Concerning the proof of God's existence
column12: he trots out David Hume's "Who made God?" which is based on a misunderstanding of the principle of causality. I refer the reader to my personal website for my version of the proof.  Let's look at two quotes
column13: the first is at the end of the chapter "Belief in Belief" and the other at the beginning of the chapter "Morality and Religion":   "That is
column14: isn't it true that
column15: whether or not God exists
column16: religious belief is at least as important as the belief in democracy
column17: in the rule of law
column18: in free will? The very widespread (but far from universal) opinion is that religion is the bulwark of morality and meaning." (p. 245)  " Without the divine carrot and stick
column19: goes this reasoning
column20: people would loll about aimlessly or indulge their basest desires
column21: beak their promises
column22: cheat on their spouses
column23: neglect their duties
column24: and so on.  There are two well-known problems with this reasoning: (1) it doesn't seem to be true
column25: which is good news
column26: since (2) is is such a demeaning view of human nature." (p. 279)  In the first chapter
column27: he mentions "bulwark of morality" and "meaning." But in the second chapter
column28: he leaves out "meaning."  If our purpose in life is not to get to heaven
column29: what is our purpose is life?   Whether religion supports morality can be determined by observing whether there is a correlation of moral conduct with religious belief. Mr. Dennett makes such a correlation to the detriment of religion by citing the high divorce rate of fundamentalist Christians.  There are worse things than divorcing your spouse. Disingenuousness can be worse and can take the form of leaving unsaid what should have been said. Mr. Dennett should have explained why he did not discuss the idea that religion gives meaning to life.  The only miracle mentioned in Mr. Dennett's book is the Shroud of Turin
column30: which has on it a mysterious image of a crucified man.  Since no one claims to know how the image got there
column31: it can be called a miracle. However
column32: Mr. Dennett does not tell us anything about it. The reader is left to find out about the famous relic by looking it up on the internet.

That aspect of her character is wholly absent in this novel.    -- on Page 276 Nina is checking out an apartment of a suspect while the teenage building manager stands in the doorway and watches. She turns to him and asks "Aren't you going to ask me what this is all about?" to which he replies "You work for the government right?" and she says "Yes."  He then asks if what she tells him could get him killed
column14: to which she also replies "Yes." and he smartly refuses to get involved.  So you're telling me that some teenage apartment manager is smarter than a trained agent  who should have
column15: and likely would have

column17: he introduces too many new characters for this to read true.  Nina and Chapelle are the only characters who are present for nearly the whole novel.  Jamie and Tony make an entrance 3/4 of the way in.  You don't have to bring Kim into it to make it believable.  Actually
column18: the only positive thing I have to say about this novel as it pertains to 24 is that he *didn't* bring in Kim or Terri.  This novel focused less on personal relationships and more on the plot.  But that's where my positive feedback begins and ends.   This novel reads

He preaches a gospel of love without justice; one in which a hippie jesus comes over and wants to chat and share his bong with you.  Holiness is apparently not all that important
column2: but then again love is all that matters.  Blue like Jazz is a waste of time and a hindrance to anyone's spiritual growth..

column1: I must admit I was skeptical when I first opened this book based on previous knowledge I had of MPD.  This book made me that much more skeptical.  In most cases of MPD or DID as it is now more commonly referred to the problem arises through the suggestive power of the therapist.  This case is different though.  On page 67 of the paperback copy I got
column2: Ms Chase describes Stanley(her name for Phillips) as wondering how it is that the personalities could seemingly communicate with each other while at the same time not being aware of each other.  Her answer that she or as she claims her "troops" give is that it is through the use of "thought transference" which was known to the ancient Greeks as she tells us later on.  I almost burst out laughing when I read that.  She also contradicts her claim that the alters don't know of each other later when she has one of them discussing the alters Rabbit and Sister Mary Catherine at the same time.  Another way this happens is how they often refer to themselves as 'we'.  Many of the alters sound as though they came from books or movies.  The abuse that she claims occurred while living with her stepfather is rather graphic.  Her claims really belong in the same realm as those who claim past life memories
column3: ufo sightings
column4: satanic ritual abuse
column5: and second sight.  I think she is not credible in the least.  There is not one fact given to support her claims of past abuse and it would be interesting for someone to write a book looking into her claims to see if there is anything that would substantiate them.  She does let us know in the book that she is very creative
column6: artistic
column7: intelligent
column8: and apparently well read.  I think this has a lot to do with her claims of multiple personalities.  The book itself is long
column9: boring
column10: anti-climatic even with the final confrontation with the stepfather which occurs at the end.  She also seems to be claiming in the book some pscyhic abilities.  Don't waste your money on this book
column11: unless you have to read it for a class as I did.

column1: There is an annoying New Agey belief grown out of religious quests for redemption and salvation that states that not only can everyone be saved
column2: everyone is wonderful and only big mean society makes them act badly. This is the kind of thinking that allows bad men (and women) to empty out bank accounts
column3: kill their spouses and excuse every one of their actions.   This movie takes an intriguing concept - Portrait of Hitler as a Young Artist - and sinks it into the morass of this kind of thinking. He's an angry man trying to make it in the art world
column4: but basically he's a good kid. He just needs a patron to support him. Unfortunately that patron gets the tar beat out of him before he can show Hitler's Autobahn as art. So Hitler decided to go with the more validating politics thing and see where that got him.   Not only do you never get the feeling that Hitler is anti-semitic or dangerous in this movie
column5: you never get the feeling that he was a man capable of using rhetoric to excite or sway audiences. This is a man that convinced an entire country to commit mass murder and this movie portrays him as a slug.  Furthermore
column6: Hitler never seems to take any responsibility for his actions. I know that sounds silly
column7: but this movie has Hitler walking around
column8: making speeches
column9: drawing pictures and somehow the rising Nazism in Germany has nothing to do with him. It's just happening outside of his realm.   Worse
column10: John Cusack plays the role as Rob Gordan from High Fidelity. Cusack is a good actor
column11: but this movie takes place in 1918
column12: not 1999. The character is not an angsty record store owner; he's a veteran whose seen more death than most can imagine. The movie doesn't even draw on the relationship between Max and Hitler as fellow veterans.  At the end of the movie you're left with the impression that Hitler was a sad little boy who could have been a great artist if only given half a chance. But instead
column13: he went to the big speech making and killed half of Europe. Doesn't really play well.  For a good movie about Hitler that focuses on both Hitler as a person and a force of history (and a man capable of wooing others to his cause) try to see if the CBS miniseries starring Robert Carlisle of Trainspotting fame is available.

column1: Going through Pilgrim at Tinker Creek with Annie Dillard I observed her skillful employment of imagery and figurative language. The use of personification
column2: similes and metaphors elevates this relatively boring story to a kaleidoscope of color and exploration. From a frog being sucked dry to peaceful eye to eye night on the rocks with a copperhead snake
column3: Dillard excites and dramatizes with unique sentence structure and personal anecdotes. The book is pregnant with telegraphic sentences and a recurring circle effect of topics. For the skillful writing and deep thought
column4: I hold a certain admiration and understanding of this book's praise. However I see little else to justify Pilgrim at Tinker Creek's winning of a Pulitzer Prize. 	Dillard's knowledge of other prevalent literature and religious books is highly noticeable throughout Pilgrim at Tinker Creek. She alludes to the Bible quite a few times in addition to the Korean and many other works
column5: including her predecessor
column6: Henry David Thoreau. Oddly enough
column7: Pilgrim at Tinker Creek bears an uncanny resembles to Thoreau's Walden. However Dillard's book lacks the same exploration into intellectual philosophy. Both books delve into the natural world with real lust for knowledge and superior curiosity. The book has a short fall
column8: in that it lacks any real substance. Full of fleshy descriptions it lacks any real soul of a thesis. Compared to Walden it is essentially similar
column9: but Walden at least has some relevant information about human nature. 	So if the microscope study the natural world is a good read
column10: then this book is for you. The details in the book on insects are fairly cacophonous
column11: which includes the mating ritual of the praying mantis. I cannot see how the book is enjoyable
column12: except for those harboring a deep love of nature. For everyone who does not fit into the extreme nature category it probably will not be very catchy
column13: but it will of essence capture an admiration for its style and imagery

column1: First of all
column2: I recommend everyone to read the book in order to have an idea where a lot of modern day values come from.   The book recognizes a problem women (as well as all other humans) have to deal with: how to find fulfillment in life. The problem is that Friedan seems to think this problem only concerns housewives and stay at home moms
column3: and that the problem could be solved by those women getting jobs outside the home. An interesting hypothesis
column4: but judging by today's women
column5: clearly wrong. There are plenty of career women that feel rather unfulfilled.   She describes the problem as women slaving away to keep the house perfectly clean and the kids perfectly taken care of
column6: and then getting depressed as a result. They do this out of a perceived societal pressure. To me
column7: the solution seems to be to check whether this is really what their kids and husband want. In reality
column8: probably no-one cares whether you wash the windows once per week or once per month
column9: so you could spend that time thinking about your values in order to raise your kids as moral individuals
column10: or learning about current events
column11: so that you can actually have a real conversation with your husband
column12: or reading a book for fun.   Getting a job because you're feeling unfulfilled trying to outperform Martha Stewart is as much of an escape tactic as becoming an alcoholic. Being a teacher is as much "living through others" as being a mother is. Shuffling papers around like people with average office jobs doesn't intrinsically give any more fulfillment than making a healthy meal for your spouse and kids does.  The book did some good in promoting equal rights for men and women
column13: but also caused a harmful movement that indoctrinates modern girls and women that the *only* path to fulfillment is through employment
column14: which is clearly nonsense. Housewives and mothers can be really valuable to society
column15: which can give them a strong sense of fulfillment.  Aside from the above
column16: the research Friedan did to back up her point was rather bad and biased
column17: with frequent misuse of statistics. A list of factual errors and omissions in her book is listed on this website:  cf.en.cl  In conclusion
column18: the book is important as a historical document

column1: Term Limits is so bad
column2: it should become a pop culture icon ala Rocky Horror Picture Show; fans should be made to wear strange clothing and recite the worst passages to music at midnight. It's so bad that by the end
column3: the act of reading has become blatant rubber-necking - ooh
column4: wow
column5: did you see that?  Ugh!   The writing is amateurish at best.  The author's favorite action verb is 'grab' and he uses it repeatedly in scenes ranging from the mundane (the grabbing of keys and doorknobs) to the romantic (the grabbing of hands and other body parts).  Similes and metaphors are conspicuously absent
column6: but there are plenty of adverbs and adverbial phrases to fill the gap.   The author switches back and forth between referring to his characters by their first and their last names; sometimes he uses one and then - in the very next sentence! - the other. "Michael grabbed her by the shoulders and turned her around. O'Rourke saw the tears in her eyes and tried to put his arms around her..."  He makes many grammatical errors
column7: the most irritating of which is the substitution of 'that' for 'who' consistently ["Congressman O'Rourke received this tape earlier today along with a letter from the assassins that were responsible for killing..."]  The dialogue is stilted and clunky - at the lowest point
column8: he has his assassin ask another character to tell him what has 'transpired' since last they talked.  Rather than simply 'saying' things
column9: the characters yell
column10: shout and scream them
column11: resulting in the unfortunate image of the president of the United States waxing shrill and screechy at his chief of staff.  The plot is neither plausible nor compelling.  The protaganists include a bunch of renegade CIA operatives who murder 'bad' politicians
column12: and a Congressman who approves of these actions and even helps to kidnap and murder a 'bad' retired CIA black ops director.  The antagonists include the aforementioned black ops director
column13: the head of the national security agency
column14: and the bumbling and ridiculous White House chief of staff.  The demand made by the 'good' assassins
column15: following their murder of four prominent politicians
column16: is that the president present a BALANCED BUDGET with NO NEW TAXES to the Congress!  Our intrepid hero-Congressman finds this a worthy cause
column17: and when some 'good' politicans (i.e. the sort who push for the balanced budget idea) are murdered
column18: he is inspired to wreak some violence of his own.  No one
column19: whether they be protagonist or antagonist
column20: seems to possess a moral compass.  'Bad' guys can be murdered indiscriminately and no consequences will be applied; the murder of a 'good' guy may be avenged
column21: again

column23: I can't reveal the ending

column25: this is some kind of silent helicopter
column26: because the people inside the house were unaware of its presence.  That this book was published at all

column1: Karen Armstrong
column2: some of whose other books I've found illuminating
column3: really fails here in a big way. This book presents a whitewashed picture
column4: a romanticised history of the founder of Islam. She carries on about "islamophobia" and the crusades but is silent about the Islamic incursions into Europe centuries before the crusades. In other words
column5: she ignores Islamic imperialism. Unfortunately
column6: it soon becomes clear that the entire book is a compendium of half-truths
column7: distortions
column8: omissions and wishful thinking.   The chapters are titled Mecca
column9: Jahilliyah
column10: Hijrah
column11: Jihad and Salam. There are 2 maps
column12: notes
column13: and a glossary without the word Dhimmitude
column14: which is very telling. The book lacks an index. The author paints Islam as a religion of peace and reconciliation and incorrectly states that the word means "peace." The real meaning of Islam is "submission"
column15: as I'm sure Ms Armstrong must know very well. She also insists on interpreting the word Jihad as "struggle" in the sense of personal struggle
column16: ignoring the numerous sayings preserved in the hadith that indicate the opposite.  What I found most shocking was Armstrong's attempts to whitewash the murder of the men of the Jewish Qurayzah tribe and the selling of the children and women into slavery. She denies Muslim anti-semitism and the inferior status and sometimes active persecution of Non-Muslims - as noted before
column17: you won't easily find the word Dhimmi in this book. Her defence of polygamy is unconvincing and comprises many pages painful to read. The tone of the book is quite touchy-feely
column18: supported by highly selective quotes from the Quran.   One wonders whether Karen Armstrong deliberately engages in intellectual dishonesty or if she just lives in a make-believe world where the frame of reference is multiculturalism
column19: relativism and postmodernism. This book is flled with distortions and romantic delusions. To get a more balanced perspective
column20: I highly recommend The Truth About Mohammed by Robert Spencer
column21: Islamic Imperialism by Efraim Karsh
column22: The Force Of Reason by Oriana Fallaci and the work of Bat Ye'or and Ayaan Hirsi Ali

 I think in retrospect I wasted my time on this one. It had a great premise that indulged me into buying this book but who knew dark days lied ahead of me. As I read through the last chapters trying to uncover the mystery, I kept on hoping that there would be something more to it, something more enigmatic, a brilliant twist but I was left with despair. My major problem with this novel was there were not enough, in fact hardly anybody whom the reader could suspect as the possible killer. And bringing out a totally new character at the very end to describe the proceedings only shows a lack of respect to the mind of the reader who had been guessing until now about various other possibilities. I will never touch this author's book again! A mantra for reading thrillers is in believing the hype and read the best of the best-Dan Brown

After quite a while I finally put the time into reading this book and I am totally ambivalent whether I should have or not...I do not think that one should pay too much attention to those readers who do not take their history seriously
column2: to those that want to propound a certain ideological agenda -- something I am realising has been
column3: and is
column4: a depressing fact of American socialisation. Those people of the ideological left will love this book and the those of the ideological right will hate it.... that is a given.   My question is this: What does Zinn have to say for the non-ideological historian? For the thinking and well considered historian
column5: the person who well distilled in classic debates of history and the role of people
column6: power and groups (classes?) in the grand scheme of things? What does Zinn have to say for those who were raised with a university education where the primary goal was to "display an adequate overview of all major acceptable views
column7: and to show a mature understanding of those views?" -- not to argue just one side. American historiography has a broad tendency to degenerate into opposite truth camps of the right and left
column8: mindlessly shouting out statistics
column9: citing dates
column10: supporting and dashing administrations to try to make a point. The entire pursuit of knowledge has been subverted by a kind of default to crude rhetoric for rhetoric's sake (see any American news programme or most prime-time columnists)
column11: and purile debate. Other countries and cultures shake their heads at such perversion of the whole idea of the way Americans understand history.    So do historians such as Zinn add to this atrophy of the brain or do they ammeliorate it? I am not so sure I know the answer. I am thinking that his whole style may betray an answer. Zinn's "radical" style is deliberately unbalanced
column12: he makes no apologies for this
column13: it is an attempt to right the largely unbalanced scales of history written by dominant elites
column14: those who have and hold the power. This is a worthy ideal
column15: but I am not so sure that a descriptive litany of abuse by those with power really says that much about an accurate interpretation of history. And if it does not
column16: then what are people actually taking away from this book...?  Anyone who reads history
column17: and I mean people who read a lot of history
column18: will find Zinn to be more than just unbalanced
column19: they will find him to be simplistic. I was caught up in his light drama (he writes well)
column20: in the same way as one reads a comic book... and then it dawned upon me... Zinn (like a left-wing version of Fox News reporting) writes as if history were a comic book. All evil on one side and all deprived and down trodden masses on by the other. For the considerate person looking for a higher understanding there will be an amazing sense of dissatisfaction
column21: a feeling of being swindled. If one is trying to achieve social justice
column22: there is a feeling of being swindled.   That may not be flattering for Mr. Zinn
column23: but I got the distinct feeling that one was dealing with a light-weight in the area of history (some of his research is hard to check
column24: he does not cite pages
column25: and I sometimes wonder if he ever cracked an economic history textbook). He certainly would not be considered up there with the grand old man Hobsbawm (who is truly an intellectual joy to read -- and a leftist with common sense!!)
column26: or Lukas(another leftist) in his great tour-de-force "Big Trouble: A Study of Class in America." Zinn does not even rate compared with these historians.   So the question I return to is this.... for the considerate person of history
column27: what does one get from this read? My conclusion is that besides some interesting vignettes on American inhumanity to man
column28: or American inhumanity to American -- not much...Even if American history is imbalanced because the "majority" or mainstream history does not pay heed to the downtrodden
column29: meeting diatribe with diatribe is neither a worthy nor reasonable approach -- moreover it is intellectually dishonest. Being biased
column30: for whatever reason
column31: is not something that historians
column32: scientists
column33: or social theoritst should TRY to be...   Historians must try to grasp a modicum of understanding through the haze of sources and alternative viewpoints. They must neither be hoodwinked by the codswallop of postmodernism or the absolute truth "certainty" of various right-wing historians. That is the challenge for the historian -- indeed it is the challenge for any thinking human being. If one wants to write comics that is a worthy endevour -- it is not however history. For a man of his age
column34: he should know better!  *If you are thinking of reading this I would say that his writing style and capturing the drama is rather good
column35: despite the fact that his sources (from the little I was able to check) are horrible.

If a person's spiritual quest leads them to examine Mormonism
column2: they will need to resolve a key issue very quickly.  That issue is:  do divinely inspired texts on which to base Christian beliefs exist outside the Bible.  If the answer is yes
column3: then a further exploration of Mormonism is possible.  If the answer is no
column4: then Mormonism is a dead end for one's spiritual growth.  That same issue has to be faced when reading A Different Jesus.  While Millet uses many citations from several Christian writers (C.S. Lewis
column5: John F. MacArthur
column6: and Luke Timothy Johnson
column7: among others) and the Bible to bolster his points
column8: the crucial source for most of his arguments are quotes from both Mormonism's sacred texts and subsequent writings by Mormon Prophets and theologians.  If an individual trying to learn about Mormonism doesn't accept the authority of these sources
column9: then Millet's arguments will make no sense.  To be fair
column10: Millet and Mouw state throughout the book that their goal is to provide a basis for understanding
column11: not conversion.  Still
column12: without accepting the central premise that Mormonism's sacred texts are divinely inspired
column13: one will end up understanding how Millet gets to his beliefs without comprehending how he could think such beliefs are true.  A Different Jesus probably would make excellent reading for anyone practicing the Mormon faith
column14: because it does highlight the differences between Mormonism and mainstream Christianity.  Additionally
column15: anyone who is trying to find their spiritual direction will likely find value in parts of the book (particularly
column16: the chapter titled "Recurring Questions").  But
column17: for those who have defined their spirituality within the context of mainstream Christianity
column18: A Different Jesus will not do much to either change their mind about Mormonism's beliefs or improve their comprehension about those beliefs

This book is about as obvious and vague as they come. Nearly ever one of the 101 topics in the book is one of four things: 1) An aspect of starting your own business that is just too obvious to put into a book like this; 2) Someone describes a lesson they learned but gives absolutely NO specifics on exactly what they did that ended up working out for their business; 3) A situation in which a person's (so-called) mistake was the only way they really learned and they worked through it to become successful. The hindsite in these is mearly wishful thinking; or 4) Norman does an absolutely horrid job of explaining what happened or how it supports the title of the lesson. I'll be honest and say that it seems as if Norman wanted to write this "101 things" book so bad

column1: I read this book because it says it was a best seller
column2: and the author is supposed to be one of the best at suspense.  With those expectations I was disappointed.  The author relies on gimmicks - like ultra short chapters to make it seem like you're reading faster.  Each chapter is 1 or 2 pages with at least one blank page between
column3: so what looks like a 400 page books is really only a 250 page short novel.  One chapter is literally a cliff-hanger.  The plot's sort of a rehash of H.G. Wells' Island Of Dr. Moreau
column4: borrowing a bit from X-Men comic books.  The mutants are all children who can fly
column5: and they're severely persecuted by their keepers
column6: so perhaps what makes the book appealing to other readers is the suspense derived from the endangered children angle
column7: another cheap gimmick.    The villains are all one-dimensional stereotypes
column8: blindly abandoning all their principles and humanity to profit off the children.  I could point out numerous flaws in style as well - but that's not the point; you could find flaws in better books too.  The point is the book is overrated for hack writing of less quality than many old pulp magazines I've read.  Even the love scenes are corny and seem like one of those cheap romance novels ("My arms were high and tight around his neck.  He pulled me against him and I felt him
column9: all of him
column10: against my thigh . . ."). The author also doesn't seem to understand the geography & terrain of the area he's writing about (for example
column11: a small Sony TV won't receive Denver channels in Gunnison National Forrest
column12: certainly not well enough to recognize faces in long shots as the author describes)
column13: and has some weird ideas of horror ("Chain link fence and concertina wire and guard dogs in the middle of the woods were scary enough
column14: but to see the words "U.S. Government" attached to "Trespassers Will Be Shot" made me ill.").  Much more like this is topped off with a liberal dose of hypocrisy:  "The arrogance and amorality of the scientists working here affronted everything I believed in.  I wanted to find one of 'them' and strangle the person with my bare hands."   This is the last time I'll buy a book because it says "best seller."  If you want to read a well-written sci-fi suspense novel in which the protagonist is a child prodigy

column1: I have been considering opening a salon for several years and have now decided to take the next step and actually do it.  I was excited to see this book because it looked like exactly what I needed but overall I was disappointed.  The material in this book is VERY basic.  It would be appropriate for someone with NO knowledge of the beauty industry or business in general.  Anyone who has any industry knowledge or who has done even the most basic research will find nothing new here.  Much of the information is basic business knowledge that I hope most people contemplating opening a business would already have.  There are a few helpful hints but they are buried in the fluff that constitutes the majority of this book - and it isn't even a big book
I rarely write reviews
column2: especially for strategy guides
column3: but once I got my hands on Mortal Kombat: Deception's strategy guide
column4: I was spurred on by a suddenly active sense of decency and concern for the well-being of MK fans the world over.  Simply put: do NOT spend $15
column5: or $10
column6: or even tree-fiddy for this guide.  No amount of financial savings will make up for the fact that this guide is useless.  The first thing I realized was that the fatalities were missing for nearly all of the characters.  Only a few random fatalities were shown
column7: I'm guessing because they needed to fill a blank space on a page with a screenshot of some sort.  Same goes for the hara-kiri moves.  Everything was incomplete
column8: except for the voluminous move lists.  Like players would rather have access to all 400 moves for every player
column9: but not the fatalities.  They're called priorities
column10: people!  The Konquest mode walkthrough (or should I say
column11: stumblethrough) is also poorly designed and confusing in its own way.  I found myself wondering where the hell I was and looking for an Outworld gas station.  (At this point
column12: I'm above any potential humiliation from asking directions to a hidden character.)  Lastly
column13: and this may be geek me talking
column14: but the guide was littered with an ungodly amount of grammatical and spelling errors on every page.  A couple of random ones I can understand
column15: but honestly
column16: I think this was either poorly translated from another language
column17: or the editing department wasn't paid enough to care if it looked any good.  So long story short
column18: get the moves/fatalities/hara-kiris/whatever from a reputable gaming site.  You'll save money
column19: and you'll get what you were looking for

column1: The curiously gifted songwriter Stephin Merritt is best known as the guiding force behind several acclaimed indie-pop groups -- most notably The Magnetic Fields
column2: who amazed
column3: delighted
column4: and sort of overwhelmed us all with the three CD collection 69 Love Songs (and then followed up with the underwhelming album i.) Over the past few years
column5: Mr. Merritt has also written songs for three music theater productions by Chen Shi-Zheng
column6: and Showtunes is jam-packed with 26 of them.  These tunes encompass everything you love (or perhaps don't?) about Stephin's songwriting -- they are clever and witty
column7: compact and concise
column8: tuneful and cloying... and a bit precious at times. There's one major problem however -- Stephin isn't singing any of them.  Instead
column9: the Showtunes are (appropriately
column10: I guess) performed by vocalists and choruses from "the original casts" in a mannered
column11: over-enunciated
column12: Broadway-esque style that sounds more like Gilbert & Sullivan than The Magnetic Fields. And sadly
column13: I couldn't stand it.  Maybe listeners more enamored of musical theater than I am would not be as distracted by this (I can't stomach Cole Porter songs sung this way either.) Besides
column14: the arrangements are fantastic
column15: using unconventional ensembles that convincingly blend Asian instruments with lute
column16: autoharp
column17: accordian
column18: marimba
column19: and steel drums -- thankfully without the electronic clutter that sometimes intrudes upon Magnetic Fields productions. (Happily
column20: a few instrumental selections are sprinkled throughout the CD.)  But unfortunately
column21: all I could think about while listening to Showtunes was how much better these songs would sound if they were sung by Merritt's soulful
column22: resonant
column23: unpretentious baritone voice instead. And I suspect that many of his other fans will feel the same way
column24: hoping as I do that Stephin has worked through this musical theater phase once and for all.  In the future
column25: if he combines the formidable songwriting and orchestration skills heard on Showtunes with the sincere and direct vocal performances that graced so many of the 69 Love Songs
column26: I expect to be amazed and delighted by Stehpin Merritt again and again.  Meanwhile
column27: be forewarned: The Magnetic Fields meets The Mikado may not be your cup of Oolong tea

column1: One minor problem for me
column2: that is evidently not a problem for many others
column3: was the art.  I was put off by the blotchy
column4: surrealistic
column5: color-schemes
column6: which were distracting
column7: and rarely added to whatever charm the line-drawings themselves possessed.  Getting past that
column8: I was able to enjoy the silly story.  Humor is often generated when the tension is created by horror or fear
column9: but then is punctured by the absurdity of the situation.    All decent people should be horrified by the idea of buying and selling other human beings
column10: in pursuit of materialistic goals
column11: as though they were mere objects.  Here
column12: however
column13: the absurdity of the situation breaks the ice.  We know that virtually no real child would want to sell his or her father.  Moreover
column14: the idea of this rather useless dad permitting himself to be bartered all over town by children
column15: without ever once looking up from his newspaper
column16: is completely nonsensical.  I suppose children might laugh (just as I did).  Another saving grace is that
column17: even though the story is told from the point of view of the creepy little sociopath of a son who sells his dad
column18: there were other characters for me to root for.  I was completely on the side of the little sister
column19: who (quite properly) objects and protests the scheme.  She (quite properly) rats him out to his mother
column20: who is also suitably furious
column21: and makes this creepy little materialist promise never to sell his dad again.  Morever
column22: since the bulk of the story concerns the quest to RECOVER the bartered-off dad
column23: even the boy is doing the right thing for much of the narrative.     But then comes the TWIST.  You see
column24: he never promised anything about not selling his little sister.  The last panel shows the brother's huge shadow
column25: mouth open with glee
column26: reaching like an ogre for this little girl
column27: who looks small
column28: isolated
column29: helpless.    This time
column30: I did not laugh.  Why not?  This time
column31: sadly
column32: the absurdity of the situation does not puncture the horror.  It is not absurd enough
column33: and it is too horrific.  We do not think the boy is joking.  Earlier in the tale
column34: we actually saw the little sister bound and gagged by the older brother to prevent her ratting on him to Mom (a disturbing enough scene in its own right).  Moreover the pictures make the boy look much larger and stronger than his little sister --  the situation lacks the obvious jokiness of bartering off one's much-larger dad while he never looks up from his newspaper.  Even the THREAT of selling your little sister to your friends is potentially a nasty and frightening form of abuse.      Gaiman's afterword tells us the story reflects real and bitter hostility that existed between two of his children
column35: and further reflected a similar bitter hostility between himself and his own sister.  This eerily suggests that the final panel might have been inspired by genuine malice.  How
column36: then is it a joke?  If bitter hostility between siblings is a problem -- and it often is -- ought not the message
column37: in a picture book ostensibly marketed for children
column38: be a bit more positive?  Payback time
column39: little girl!  I guess she shouldn't have ratted out her creepy older brother.  Funny to Gaiman
column40: perhaps
column41: but not to me

column1: David Fromkin's "Peace to End All Peace" is simultaneously a comprehensive and very flawed work. Many of the reasons for it being one can be found in the other.  Fromkin attempts to examine how the modern Middle East (extending as far as Afghanistan and some sections of Central Asia) was created during and after the First World War. Obviously
column2: in order to do this
column3: the fall of the Ottoman Empire in that war must be considered. This is where Fromkin's unusual methodology comes into play. Focusing on the European political machinations to resolve the "Eastern Question" in their favour
column4: the sorry tale becomes one more of Churchill and TE Lawrence than of the Arabs and Turks who were also involved in the process. Admittedly
column5: it was the Europeans who wielded the whip hand in deciding just where the borders were to be drawn
column6: but reducing key figures such as the CUP Triumvirate in the dying Ottoman Empire (and Kemal Ataturk in Turkey immediately thereafter) to the status of supporting players ultimately skews the focus of the book too much.  Never let it be said that this is a simple story to retell. A complex web of national and personal political interests in both Europe and the Middle East combined to make the region what it is today
column7: and any study of all of these will be faced with the need for convoluted explanations. The problem that Fromkin has
column8: however
column9: is that he does not make these very well at all. The story is told in a roughly chronological manner
column10: which means that we jump from place to place and meet a bewildering array of characters. Ultimately
column11: the only real result is confusion on the part of the reader
column12: who is constantly flipping backwards to see who the latest figure to make an appearance actually is.  Additionally
column13: Fromkin frequently confuses his readers with references to geographical features which are not well-shown on the maps provided. Indeed
column14: one map (showing Enver Pasha's advance on Baku and his campaigns in Central Asia) is laughable in the extreme. The legend explains that the direction of the arrows is the direction of the various advances - which would be significantly more useful were the arrows in fact arrows
column15: and not equilateral triagles.  Where Fromkin does well
column16: however
column17: is in his use of purely European sources. It is perhaps unusual to say this of a book intending to tell the story of the modern Middle East
column18: but I have considerable doubts about the depth of his research into the Middle Eastern aspects of the events in question. In terms of Europe
column19: however
column20: his research seems to cover the major bases of exactly what the key figures believed and did.  Ultimately
column21: "A Peace to End All Peace" is a difficult and not particularly rewarding work. A diplomatic history of Europe during the Great War can be written much better than this
column22: and a history of the development of the Middle East following that conflict already has been (the chapters in Margaret Attwood's "The Peacemakers" or William Cleveland's "Modern Middle East" both easily outshine this)

column1: It has been 15 years since I last shopped for a stereo receiver
column2: and back then there were certain features that all receivers came with
column3: regardless of how basic or inexpensive the model was.  Well
column4: I took for granted that they all still came with these basic features
column5: and I was wrong.  I just purchased the Sherwood RX-4105
column6: and it does not have the tape monitoring feature.  It has tape input and output jacks
column7: but it doesn't have the monitoring feature that lets you listen to the tape deck's output while you are recording.  If you press the tape button
column8: the receiver switches away from the input source you are trying to record from!  The tape monitor function is also necessary for the use of an equalizer.  It baffles me that they are still giving you tape in and out jacks
column9: but don't give you the proper switching for monitoring.  I guess they figured they could save a few pennies by leaving out this function
column10: since the demand for tape decks has declined in recent years.  Unfortunately
column11: there are those of us who still like to use an EQ to customize the sound to our environment
column12: even if we are no longer recording on tape.  I have found it difficult to verify whether or not a receiver has this function
column13: since the specs and features list usually never mentions it.  If they have a good picture of the unit
column14: you can look to see if there is a button that says "tape monitor."  Just looking for tape in and out jacks will not help
column15: because as I mentioned above
column16: the RX-4105 has these jacks
column17: but no monitor function.  Then there are some models that have monitoring even though the switch only says "tape."  The best way to know for sure is to try out the unit first
column18: but this is not practical when shopping online.  I have even gone so far as to go to the manufacturer's website and download the instruction manual.  If the section on tape connections and recording doesn't mention "monitoring
column19:
it probably doesn't have it.  Also, many models no longer have phono input, but this is easy to check just by looking at a good picture of the unit.  The RX-4105 also lacks an auxillary AC jack on the back of the unit; not a big deal, but a consideration if you have an outlet strip already filled up by other components. Another thing I noted that is worth mentioning is that many newer models such as this one have volume control knobs that do not have any position indicators or scale markings on them; so be sure to turn down the volume before you turn off the unit, or you could be in for a surprise when you turn it back on again!  If you don't intend to use an EQ, and don't need phono input, the RX-4105 is probably a good inexpensive starter model.  The sound seemed fine, and it had plenty of power for my application.  The tuner did seem to have a weak sensitivity; some local FM stations came in with a lot of static.    In my research I have found the TEAC models RV-S2100 and AG-790, as well as Onkyo models TX-8011 and TX-8211 all have tape monitoring capabilities as well as phono input.

column1: ***This is a discussion about certain points in the book
column2: and may be considered to some a spoiler
column3: so please do not read if you want to remain surprised about the book's high points and/or outcome.***  I expected to read this book and feel inspired by the obstacles that were overcome by Chris Gardner as he rose from a poverty-stricken child living the hard knock life to a successful adult with many moral achievements. However
column4: this was not the case. Shortly into the book
column5: I came to realize that most of Mr. Gardner's problems were self-created. Sure
column6: his upbringing was a contributory factor to some of his issues. But mostly
column7: he made some very bad choices that resulted in some very bad outcomes.  First
column8: I disliked how he constantly put his mother
column9: the woman who allowed herself and her children to be beaten time and time again by her husband
column10: on a pedastool. This was a woman who went to prison twice
column11: once for welfare fraud and once for attempted murder
column12: yet we are to believe she was the epitomy of moral conscience? In all fairness
column13: it is respectable that Mr. Gardner continued to idolize his mother
column14: even after his rough childhood and the abuse to which he was subjected at home. However
column15: this woman exemplified so many reasons why she was the complete opposite of an ideal role model for a child.  Second
column16: I thought it extremely irresponsible of Mr. Gardner to discuss not being able to afford to put food on the table for his wife and child some days
column17: and in the next sentence to talk about getting high with his buddies to "take the edge off". Certainly the drugs were not always free. Was he spending the family's grocery money on drugs?   Third
column18: I disliked how he rationalized listening to jokes containing the infamous "N" word from the rich oil tycoon
column19: simply because this same man was fattening his pockets at the time. This tells the world that such a situation is acceptable
column20: so long as someone benefits enough to overlook the insulting word. I also found it absolutely disgusting how Mr. Gardner
column21: immediately upon hearing of this oil tycoon's death
column22: sold every bit of stock in the man's portolio
column23: even though he himself admitted that all stock sales should immediately halt once an estate is in probate. Mr. Gardner stated that the oil tycoon
column24: in the days before his death
column25: had requested that all of his portfolio assets be liquidated (never mind the history of 30-35% capital gains)
column26: and that Mr. Gardner was only carrying out his final "orders". I call Mr. Gardner's bluff on this one - he sold that stock just to make a final commission. Mr. Gardner showed a true lack of ethics in this situation.  Finally
column27: and most disturbing
column28: was how Mr. Gardner sent his son to live with Jackie after she had already once abandoned the child. She had proven herself once to be an unfit mother
column29: yet Mr. Gardner sent his son across the country to live with her after he starting achieving personal financial success in Chicago. If his main concern was the welfare of his child
column30: why did he not keep little Chris with him?  Overall
column31: I am completely dissapointed with this book. Mr. Gardner may be hailed as a hero to some
column32: but he is most certainly not a hero to me.

column1: This book is not what I expected.  It's more of a "workbook" instead of a book to read.  I was thoroughly disappointed
This book starts with an outright lie: George of Capadocia was murdered by a PAGAN mob. As bishop of Alexandria
column2: he had done more to piss off pagans than anybody in the history of the Roman Empire. It was only after Julian had come out of the pagan closet that they felt safe enough to act against George. Athanasius' followers played a minimal part
column3: if any
column4: in that incident.   No contemporary sources attest to the manner of Arius' death. This supposedly was a story circulated by Athanasius decades after the fact
column5: and then retold a few more decades later by historian Socrates. Anybody familiar with the depiction of Judas' death in the Book of Acts can see what Athanasius was getting at: Arius was another Judas. At the time of his death
column6: Arius had long ceased being a player in church politics and his reinstatement was an act of charity to a forgotten old man
column7: not a triumphant vindication. There was nothing to be gained by murdering him.   The author states that if a Council ever deserved to be called ecumenical it was that of Rimini-Seleucia. Hardly. If there was ever a Council that was rigged to produced a desired result (beginning with the idea of dividing it into two venues to better isolate Athanasius' followers)
column8: it was that of Rimini-Seleucia.  And so on. In this book so many creative liberties have been taken with the facts that it becomes impossible to tell what is conjecture and what is historical. Not to mention the absurd conflation of Adoptionist and Gnostic ideas being presented as Arianism by the author.  Other reviewers have pointed out the author is not a theologian or historian. Indeed
column9: it is worse than that: he is a LAWYER. Lawyers are not trained to get at the truth. Lawyers are trained to win their cases by any "legal" means necessary. For whatever reason
column10: the author seems to be out to destroy the reputation of the Christian witnesses and to discredit their testimony. You would never guess from this book that the Church during this period did a single positive thing.  Moreover
column11: I think there is something disturbingly inappropriate about the publication of a book written by a person of a religious background which derisively speculates about another religion's origins. In the century before and the century after the birth of Jesus
column12: Judaism was a battleground between different factions at least as brutal as the Christianity depicted by this author
column13: if not worse. If I
column14: a Christian
column15: were to publish a book which speculated about the legitimacy of the Judaism which emerged from that struggle
column16: I hope I would get severely criticized
column17: to say the least. Maybe that's the book Mr. Rubinstein should have written instead.  I give this book one star to counter the high reviews it's been getting from readers who take it at face value as a source of Church history. The best advice to readers is to approach this book as one would the Da Vinci Code: a historical kernel lies somewhere within a liberally and creatively elaborated story. But if you want a real Church history which is well-balanced and easy to read
column18: I recommend picking up Chadwick's "The Early Church" instead

column1: This book does not offer much more than the Sun J2EE Tutorial online does and that is free. I have worked through the first two weeks

column3: binding
column4: and lookup. After this the book is nothing more than a rehash of the Sun Online tutorial with a different larger example application. The application is complete. You don't do anything but read about the design and pertinent Java technologies that are being used for that particular part of the application. Then you are given instructions on how to deploy the current working piece of the application on the J2EE RI
column5: and run sample clients against it - chapter after chapter of the same thing. Though this type of learning by reading some one else code with explanations seems to be enjoyed by some. I side with Ivor Horton. Programming is not a spectator sport. You learn by doing. Having the reader build the application and participate in the process would have made for a better learning experience of a complex topic

column1: AGELESS BODY is Deepak's attempt to neutralize the word "old" as in old age.  The writer has a knack for making common words
column2: like "body
column3: "mind" and "self
column4: into profound concepts.  His technique is to overlay his abstract ideas with suggestive experimental studies.  But ambiguity in interpreting these studies abound.  	If you like poetry, Deepak may be your read: The billions of changes occurring in our cells are only the passing scenery of life; (P. 36)"  Or try to interpret this one: "The emptiness at the core of every atom is the womb of the universe; in the flicker of thought when two neurons interact there is an opportunity for a new world to be born. (P.40)"   	At times he attributes to cells and DNA a creative intelligence to direct their own construction and at other times his designer is invisible.  He would make a great spokesman for the current hocus pocus over "intelligent design."  He can't accept the growth of any cell
column5: even a plant cell
column6: without an intelligence involved.  He mentions and attacks evolution only one time on P. 115
column7: asserting that the growth of a cell could never be a random process.  	Deepak ends up in the very same thought circle as every other writer who tries to explain life in scientific terms: Intelligence is a self organizing entity and every cell evolved is only intelligence having a conversation with itself.  Whether your word game tosses in the word "quantum" or not doesn't change much.  What a solipsistic thought; what a solipsistic world.  I wonder if his readers who actually experienced the oneness Deepak speaks of wouldn't
column8: after awhile
column9: go insane

column1: Intensely homophobic
column2: heterosexist
column3: and hateful
column4: this film represents the twisted fears and logic of the early panic stage of the disease in the 1980s. It was a time when the public was eager to pin the epidemic squarely on the shoulders of gay men
column5: blaming antisocial "AIDS carriers" for carelessly or intentionally infecting chaste wives and innocent babies. It was a time when the public blamed AIDS on lust-driven
column6: irresponsible gay men and cheating husbands. The film is pretentious and overbearing in its failed attempt to masquerade as a sophisticated inquiry into moral responsibility in the age of HIV. It reinforces the simplistic outdated idea that those who are infected with HIV can be neatly separated into the categories of "deserving" or "undeserving" - immoral monsters and their innocent victims sitting together on death row. Twenty years ago
column7: perhaps this film would have its place as a document reflecting our social ignorance and failures in coping with a new epidemic. We did not know then that HIV was a predominantly heterosexual global pandemic. Today this film is a sophomoric attempt to assign blame and reinforce old prejudices about HIV and HIV+ people. Most importantly
column8: HIV is no longer a death sentence to Americans who discover their status and enter medical treatment early. As someone who counsels and tests hundreds of people for HIV infection every year
column9: I would not recommend this film to anyone seeking knowledge or entertainment

column1: Rory is a high-school student and a talented artist.  The artistic part isn't surprising--her father is a painter and has been teaching Rory how to draw and paint since she was a very small child.  Her happiest memories involve her father and art.  So it is especially devastating when Rory finds her father kissing another woman.  When he leaves her and her mother
column2: Rory feels like it is her fault for confronting him and being so angry.  With her father gone
column3: Rory loses her ability to draw or paint.  She tries to remember the things he taught her
column4: but she can't hear his voice any longer.  It seems she may never regain her artistic abilities
column5: unless her father agrees to come home again.  This story has a good premise
column6: but I felt like it was too short to really address how Rory would be okay again.  Being able to talk to her father would certainly help
column7: but I think she would also have to focus on her relationship with her mother.  Both of them were broken after her father left
column8: and in order to get their lives back they would have to learn to rely on each other more.  Nothing in this story dealt with that relationship.  Instead
column9: the author made it seem like Rory would be fine as long as she had her father's support
column10: regardless of her mother's state of mind.

column1: I was shocked by the poor quality of the writing from such a well-known author.  Though published in 1995
column2: the reader is expected to ignore the then-well-known realities of DNA testing -- for instance
column3: that shared parentage can be proved by comparing the DNA of siblings
column4: not just from putative sibling to parent.  We're also asked to ignore the realities of fingerprint identification when it would have been immediately helpful in revealing an imposter's criminal record and actual identity.    Adding insult to injury
column5: after ignoring the technique when it logically would have come into play
column6: Sheldon brings in fingerprinting at the very tail of the book
column7: in a complicated scenario involving latent prints to identify not the missing heiress
column8: but rather
column9: a private detective!    Every plot development was telegraphed in advance
column10: and the decedent went from being rather interesting in the first few pages to a one-dimensional (and repetitive) demon throughout the rest of the too-long tome.  Even the vocabulary and sentence structure were overly simplistic.  If you want to read the identical plot but done WELL
column11: try "Amanda" by Kay Hooper
column12: also published in 1995.  Hooper has her character do some marvelously stupid things (again
column13: failing to exploit DNA to the fullest in a timely way)
column14: but Hooper's vocabulary
column15: syntax
column16: character development and settings are vastly better than the careless work Sheldon provides in "Morning
column17: Noon
column18: & Night."  I read the books only a week apart.  Hooper's work was engaging
column19: though somewhat predictable; Sheldon's was irritating
column20: and ENTIRELY predictable.
